[[Niecy Nash]]
[[Robert Ben Garant]]
[[Thomas Lennon]]
[[Carlos Alazraqui]]
[[Wendi McLendon-Covey]]
[[Kerri Kenney-Silver]]
[[Mary Birdsong]]
[[Ian Roberts (American actor)|Ian Roberts]]
[[Joe Lo Truglio]] | country = United States | network = [[Comedy Central]] | company = Jersey Television
Comedy Central Productions | distributor = [[MGM Television|MGM Worldwide Television Distribution]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2003|7|23}} | last_aired = {{End date|2009|7|8}} | num_seasons = 6 | num_episodes = 88 | list_episodes = List of Reno 911! episodes | camera = [[Videotape]]; [[Single camera]] | website = http://www.comedycentral.com/shows/reno_911/index.jhtml | website_title = Official website }} '''''Reno 911!''''' is an American [[television comedy|comedy]] television series on [[Comedy Central]] that ran from 2003 to 2009. It is a [[mockumentary]]-style parody of law enforcement [[documentary television series|documentary]] shows, specifically ''[[Cops (TV series)|Cops]]'', with comic actors playing the [[police officer]]s. Most of the material is [[improvisational comedy|improvised]], using a broad outline with minimal scripted material. The series spawned a film, ''[[Reno 911!: Miami]]'', featuring the same cast. [[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]], [[Robert Ben Garant]] and [[Kerri Kenney-Silver]] all starred in and are billed as creators of the series. ==Premise== The show is a direct [[satire]] of the iconic [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Television]] series, ''[[Cops (TV series)|Cops]]'' (which follows actual police officers through their daily duties, such as chasing criminals, and intervening in domestic disputes). ''Reno 911!'' features members of the fictitious, massively inept "Reno Sheriff's Department"—distinct from the actual Reno Police Department, and, Washoe County Sheriff's Office, both of which are absent from the series (although Comedy Central has repeatedly referenced the series as being about the "men and women of the Washoe County Sheriff's Department").{{cite web |url=http://www.cc.com/shows/reno-911- |title=Reno 911 |author=Comedy Central |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180628022011/http://www.cc.com/shows/reno-911- |archive-date=2018-06-28 |accessdate=2018-06-28 }} In the course of their duties patrolling both the city of [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]] and the rest of [[Washoe County, Nevada|Washoe County]], [[Nevada]], the deputies sometimes address the camera directly (as though being interviewed for a documentary). The show deals heavily in [[politically incorrect]] and racy humor, including many jokes about [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[sexual orientation]], [[substance abuse]], [[rape]], [[pedophilia]], and [[mental disorder]]s. Another main comedic aspect of the show is the outlandishly severe incompetence of the deputies—often resulting in their being outsmarted by the criminals they are attempting to control. [[File:Orpheus RENO 911 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Lennon and Kenney-Silver in character at Mardi Gras]] Only the basic plot elements of the show are scripted, while the dialogue is [[improvisational comedy|improvised]]—enhancing the illusion of reality (a practice referred to as [[retroscripting]]). Unlike ''Cops'', which the show parodies, ''Reno 911!'' Sheriff's deputies are constantly cursing, causing much of their dialogue to be censored for broadcast. The actors often perform their own stunts. A constantly changing cast of weirdos, prostitutes, homeless persons, survivalists, political figures, celebrities, etc. are portrayed by comedian friends of the primary cast, and the cast themselves, while disguising their voices and general appearance (and, whose faces were blurred in the style of ''Cops''). The show's characters occasionally refer to their own program. They insist that the show's producers told them the videotaped [[footage]] was going to be used for a [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Television]] [[Documentary film|documentary]] series titled ''Heroes on Patrol''; and, often stated in frustration, that they have no control over what is aired, and that the show only seems to capture their 'moments' of incompetence. The many "good" incidents, they allege, are left out of the (show-within-a-show's) final edit. Also, some suspects in the show refer to the film crew, and the program being aired on television; occasionally, they will attempt to get arrested just to be on TV. ==Development history== In Thomas Lennon's words, ''Reno 911!'' came about, "like the best of ideas, through total desperation."[[The Sound of Young America]]: [http://www.maximumfun.org/blog/2008/05/podcast-reno-911s-stars-and-creators.html Interview with Thomas Lennon, Robert Ben Garant, and Kerri Kenney-Silver, May 22, 2008.] Following the end of ''[[Viva Variety]]'', ''[[The State (1993 TV series)|The State]]'' alumni worked on a series of pilots for Fox Television, one of which, after a year's worth of dedicated writing, was terminated the day before shooting. It was scheduled to begin in the fall of 2000.{{Cite web| last = Topel| first = Fred| authorlink = | coauthors = | title = One on One with Cedric Yarbrough| work = | publisher = about.com| year = 2007| url = http://movies.about.com/od/reno911miami/a/reno911cy021607.htm| doi = | accessdate = April 3, 2009}} With a month left before the pilot was expected to be due (and half of the budget still unused), the team asked if they could produce another pilot with the remaining resources, and the Fox executives agreed. Working quickly to take advantage of this, the initial ''Reno 911!'' pilot was conceived and shot in five days. [[Cedric Yarbrough]], who had been hired for the cast of the canceled pilot, said that the cast was advised to "come up with [their] own characters" and return for filming. As originally written, the sheriff's department material would have served as link material between traditional comedy sketches; the canceled project was being considered for the Fox Saturday lineup, and the team thought at the time that the ''Cops'' format was a natural framework for sketch comedy. However, during the shooting—and especially the editing—they realized the police element was more interesting than the sketches, and the finished pilot was, according to Robert Ben Garant, "remarkably similar" to the series that eventually aired. Nevertheless, Fox turned down the completed pilot. According to Lennon, their decision not to pick the show up was influenced by a scene, preserved in the eventual Comedy Central pilot, involving Lt. Dangle passionately kissing a man. It was another two years before Comedy Central greenlit the project. ==Production== The establishing shots for the show were filmed in [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]], and everything else was filmed in [[Carson, California]], and some parts of [[Oregon]]. Many of the main scenes of the show were shot over the course of many hours, such as the briefing room scenes. According to the [[DVD]] commentary for season three, all morning briefing scenes for a season may be filmed on one 10-hour day with different basic plot elements to be used in different episodes. Actors would contribute their dialogue as they were inspired to do so. The show was continued for two additional seasons with [[Comedy Central]] running a special of the show titled ''Reno 911!: Off Duty'' on March 21, 2004. The fourth season began on July 9, 2006 and comprised 14 episodes. Comedy Central aired the first seven in the fall of 2006 and the last seven in the spring of 2007. Also in early 2007, a theatrical film based upon the series entitled ''[[Reno 911!: Miami]]'' was released in North America, featuring the complete TV series cast. The Season Four spring debut drew 1.3 million viewers during the week of March 26 to April 1, 2007. Excess footage from season three was used in season four. On October 9, 2006, Comedy Central confirmed 13 new episodes to make up ''Reno 911!'' Season Five, though the season actually contained 16 episodes. Production of Season Five started in January and wrapped up in April. ''Reno 911!'' Season Five premiered on January 16, 2008. On March 27, 2007, [[WGN America|Superstation WGN]] acquired the first four seasons of the half-hour comedy for a two-year run. The syndicated ''Reno 911!'' is a part of their late night comedy block. Reruns are syndicated to broadcast stations. In 2007, Lennon and Garant later appeared in-character on a comedy compilation CD, ''[[Comedy Death-Ray (album)|Comedy Death-Ray]]'', released on September 11, singing a song about why not to use drugs. On November 10, 2008, Comedy Central confirmed 10 new episodes to make up ''Reno 911!'' Season Six, the final season. Principal photography was done between November and December 2008. [[Carmen Electra]] was a guest star on an episode filmed December 5, 2008 at [[Grant High School (Los Angeles, California)|Grant High School]] in Los Angeles. Season Six premiered on April 1, 2009 on Comedy Central. Season Six consisted of fifteen episodes. Cast members Carlos Alazraqui, Wendi McLendon-Covey, and Mary Birdsong did not return for the final season and their characters' absence was explained as fatalities from an explosion in the Season Five finale. In addition, actors [[Ian Roberts (American actor)|Ian Roberts]] and [[Joe Lo Truglio]] were added to the principal cast as Sergeant Jack Declan and Deputy Frank Salvatore Rizzo, respectively. On August 13, 2009, Thomas Lennon announced through Twitter that the show had ended its six-year run.[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/blogs/live-feed/comedy-central-cancels-reno-911-52072 Comedy Central Cancels "Reno"], ''Hollywood Reporter'', August 13, 2009 In response to the cancellation, residents and officials of [[Reno, Nevada]] petitioned to save the show.Jayne Clark. [https://www.usatoday.com/travel/destinations/2009-08-27-save-reno-911_N.htm "'Reno 911!': The city it mocks tries to save it,"] ''USA Today''. August 27, 2009. Retrieved 2010-06-07. ===Discussed Netflix revival=== In October 2011, a story broke that the producers of ''Reno 911!'' were in negotiations with the popular internet streaming website [[Netflix]] to revive the cancelled [[Comedy Central]] series.[http://www.afterdawn.com/news/article.cfm/2011/10/09/netfix_looking_to_revive_reno_911 Netflix looking to revive Reno 911!], "Afterdawn.com", October 9, 2011 The main reason ''Reno 911!''{{'}}s producers wanted to revive the show was because only 88 episodes were produced, the producers and syndicating networks would have liked for the show to hit the 100 episode milestone.[http://www.vulture.com/2011/10/netflix_brings_back_reno_911.html Netflix wants to Make New Episodes of Reno 911!], "Vulture.com" However, at the time, Comedy Central, who still held sole rights to the show, had not been involved in any negotiations. As well, [[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]] and [[Robert Ben Garant]] were attached to other projects. ==Episodes== {{Main|List of Reno 911! episodes}} {{:List of Reno 911! episodes}} ==Cast and characters== ===Characters=== {{Main|Characters on Reno 911!}} ===Cast history=== [[File:Reno cast v8.jpg|300px|thumb|left|]] * Thomas Lennon, Kerri Kenney-Silver, Ben Garant, Joe Lo Truglio, frequent ''Reno 911!'' director [[Michael Patrick Jann]] and many of the frequent guest stars are members of ''[[The State (1993 TV series)|The State]]'', a comedy troupe who had a popular sketch series which aired for three seasons on [[MTV]] in the early 1990s. * Lennon and Kenney-Silver were the stars of ''[[Viva Variety]]'', a former [[Comedy Central]] series. Their co-star, [[Michael Ian Black]], has appeared in several ''Reno 911!'' episodes. Garant was ''Viva Variety''{{'}}s head writer and co-creator; it was a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of a sketch on ''The State''. * McLendon-Covey was a member of [[The Groundlings]] theater company, located in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]. She was dismissed from ''Reno 911!'' prior to the sixth season.{{citation|url=http://www.premiumhollywood.com/tag/mary-birdsong-leaves-reno-911/|title=Cast changes have hurt "Reno 911!"|author=Paulsen, John|date=April 21, 2009}} * Alazraqui is the voice of many cartoon characters, such as: Mr. Weed from ''[[Family Guy]]'' (1999–2001); Lazlo and Clam from ''[[Camp Lazlo]]''; Rocko from ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]''; Winslow and Lube from ''[[CatDog]]''; Monroe the enchanted dog from ''[[The Life and Times of Juniper Lee]]''; the [[Taco Bell Chihuahua]] and, Denzel Crocker from ''[[The Fairly OddParents]]''. He was the voice of ''[[Spyro the Dragon (character)|Spyro the Dragon]]'' in that series' first installment. Alazraqui is also the voice of the [[Disney]] character [[Panchito Pistoles|Panchito]], of ''[[The Three Caballeros]]'' and classic cartoon character [[Felix the Cat]]. * Nash was the host of ''[[Clean House]]'' on the [[Style Network]]. She appeared in ''[[Cookie's Fortune]]'', also as a cop. * Yarbrough is the voice of Assistant District Attorney Tom DuBois and Col. Stinkmeaner in the cartoon version of ''[[The Boondocks (TV series)|The Boondocks]]'' and plays a prison guard in the film ''[[Meet the Fockers]]'', and an Army sergeant in an episode of ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]''. He also played [[pimp]] "Chocolate Giddyup" in the movie ''[[Black Dynamite]]''. * Birdsong worked on several Comedy Central programs prior to joining the cast of ''Reno 911!'' She appeared in programs such as ''[[The Daily Show]]''; ''[[Crossballs]]''; ''[[Contest Searchlight]]''; and, ''[[Lewis Black's Root of All Evil]]''. Before joining ''Reno 911!'' as a main cast member, Birdsong made a guest appearance in season 2 as Lisa, a Caucasian woman disguised as a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] masseuse. She won a Theatre World Award in 2007 for her Broadway debut with [[Martin Short]] in the musical "Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me!" She may have been dismissed from ''Reno 911!'' prior to season six. * Season six newcomers Joe Lo Truglio and Ian Roberts were no strangers to ''Reno 911!''. Both had appeared as guest stars in past seasons, and both also appeared in ''Reno 911: Miami''. As a member of ''The State'', Lo Truglio is an old friend of the three creators and has worked with them on numerous projects. Roberts is a founding member of the popular [[Upright Citizens Brigade]] improv comedy troupe, who had their own Comedy Central sketch show from 1998-2000. Other remaining members of the troupe ([[Matt Besser]] and [[Matt Walsh (comedian)|Matt Walsh]]) also appeared in recurring guest roles throughout the seasons. [[Amy Poehler]] is the only member of the ''"UCB'' 4" to have never appeared on the show in any form. Throughout the show's run, all three main cast members from ''[[Stella (U.S. TV series)|Stella]]'' (who were also from ''The State'') made appearances as characters. While [[Michael Showalter]] was the exception on the TV series, he appeared in the [[Reno 911!: Miami|film]], along with all of the cast members of ''The State''. {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="cornsilk" |align=center colspan=5|'''"The State" Crossovers ''' |- bgcolor="Cornsilk" ! Actor ! On Reno 911! ! On Reno 911: Miami |- bgcolor="white" | '''[[Thomas Lennon]]''' | Lt. Jim Dangle | Lt. Jim Dangle |- bgcolor="white" | '''[[Robert Ben Garant]]''' | Deputy Travis Junior | Deputy Travis Junior |- bgcolor="white" | '''[[Kerri Kenney-Silver]]''' | Deputy Trudy Wiegel | Deputy Trudy Wiegel |- bgcolor="white" | '''[[Michael Patrick Jann]]''' | Director | Tattoo Shop Owner #1 |- bgcolor="white" | '''[[Joe Lo Truglio]]''' | Shopkeeper (1 episode)
Deputy Frank Rizzo (recurring) | Tattoo Shop Owner #2 |- bgcolor="white" | [[Ken Marino]] | Frank
Cadet Jared Reese
Sgt. Andrew Blake | Deaf Tattoo Artist |- bgcolor="white" | [[David Wain]] | Sensual Masseur
Sam | Breen the Plumber |- bgcolor="white" | [[Michael Ian Black]] | Kevin the Sex Offender
Chris | Ron of Ron's Tattoo |- bgcolor="white" | [[Kevin Allison]] | N/A | Tattoo Victim |- bgcolor="white" | [[Michael Showalter]] | N/A | Paul |- bgcolor="white" | [[Todd Holoubek]] | N/A | Tattooed Guy |} ===Main crew members=== * [[Danny DeVito]] – Executive Producer * [[Michael Shamberg]] – Executive Producer * [[Stacey Sher]] – Executive Producer * [[John Landgraf]] – Executive Producer * Peter Principato – Executive Producer * Paul Young – Executive Producer * [[Ben Garant|Robert Ben Garant]] – Creator * [[Kerri Kenney-Silver]] – Creator * [[Thomas Lennon (actor)|Thomas Lennon]] – Creator * [[Michael Patrick Jann]] – Director ==Film== {{Main|Reno 911!: Miami}} The series spawned a film released in 2007. In the film, the deputies are called in to save the day after a terrorist attack disrupts a national police convention and locks over 2000 police officers in a hotel in [[Miami Beach]] during spring break. In December 2017, Nash said another film is in the works.{{cite web|last1=Malkin|first1=Marc|title='Reno 911!' Movie in the Works, Says Star Niecy Nash|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/reno-911-movie-works-says-star-niecy-nash-1069277|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=19 December 2017}} ==Home media== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%;" !width="240px"| DVD title !width="90px"| Release date !{{Abbr|No.|Number}} of
episodes !Additional information |-valign="top" |The Complete First Season||June 22, 2004|| align="center" |14|| Alternate Scenes, Audio Commentary from the entire cast. |-valign="top" |The Complete revision.comment: There's a difference between scar and schar. Both actual schools at GMU. whoops.
revision.text:
{{Infobox college | name = The School for Conflict Analysis and Resolution (S-CAR) | image_name = Logo_for_George_Mason_University_and_the_School_for_Conflict_Analysis_and_Resolution.png | image_size = 100 | established = March 1981 | type = [[Public University]] |academic_affiliation = [[George Mason University]] | dean = [[Kevin Avruch]]{{cite web|url=http://newsdesk.gmu.edu/2013/09/kevin-avruch-named-dean-school-conflict-analysis-resolution/ |title=Kevin Avruch Named Dean of the School for Conflict Analysis and Resolution |publisher=George Mason University News |date=2013-09-27 |accessdate=2014-06-14}} | location = [[Arlington, VA]], [[United States|USA]]
[[Fairfax, VA]], [[United States|USA]]
[[Lorton, VA]], [[United States|USA]] | postgrad =201{{cite web |url=http://irr.gmu.edu/Unitprofile1314/fastfacts.cfm?UNITID=CA&DIVSNAME=School%20for%20Conflict%20Analysis%20and%20Resolution |title=George Mason University Institutional Research & Reporting |publisher= |date=2013 |accessdate=2014-06-19 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | undergrad =208 | website = [https://scar.gmu.edu/ S-CAR Website] }} The '''School for Conflict Analysis and Resolution''' (S-CAR) is a division of [[George Mason University]] based near [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] with locations in Arlington, Fairfax, and Lorton, Virginia. == History == S-CAR was founded in 1981 as the Center for Conflict Analysis, later named the Center for Conflict Analysis and Resolution (CCAR) and began offering a master's degree in Conflict Analysis and Resolution in 1983. In 1988 it became the first academic institution to grant PhD's in Conflict Analysis and Resolution and rose to the status of Institute, becoming ICAR in 1989.{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/newsletter-subject/icar-then-and-now-institute-turns-25-years-old |title=ICAR Then and Now: The Institute Turns 25 Years Old |publisher=S-CAR News, Special Issue: Point of View |date=February 2008|accessdate=2014-06-14}} In 2010, after a decade of growth and development, including the introduction of the undergraduate program and graduate certificate programs, it became the School for Conflict Analysis and Resolution (S-CAR).{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/newsletter-subject/icar-becomes-school-reflections-past-and-looking-future |title=ICAR Becomes a School: Reflections on the past and looking to the future |publisher=S-CAR News, Volume 5, Issue 1 |date=February 2011|accessdate=2014-06-14}} == Academic programs{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/academics-and-centers |title= S-CAR Academics Page |publisher=scar.gmu.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-17}}== *PhD - Doctorate of Philosophy *MS - Master of Science in Conflict Analysis and Resolution *BA/BS - Bachelor of Arts or Science in Conflict Analysis and Resolution *Graduate Certificates in Conflict Analysis and Resolution{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/certificate-program/9482 |title= S-CAR Graduate Certificates Programs Page |publisher=scar.gmu.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-17}} **Conflict Analysis and Resolution Advanced Skills ** Conflict Analysis and Resolution Collaborative Leadership in Community Planning **Conflict Analysis and Resolution for Prevention, Reconstruction and Stabilization **World Religions, Diplomacy and Conflict Resolution *Dual master's degree with the [[University of Malta]] - Master of Science in Conflict Analysis and Resolution and Master of Arts in Conflict Resolution and Mediterranean Security{{cite web|url=http://newsdesk.gmu.edu/2014/03/two-degrees-two-schools-one-year-mason-malta/ |title=Two Degrees, Two Schools, One Year: Mason and Malta |publisher=George Mason University News |date=2013-09-27 |accessdate=2014-06-14}} *Dual Degree - Master of Science in Conflict Analysis and Resolution and Master of Social Work{{cite web|url=https://chhs.gmu.edu/msw/dual-degree.cfm |title=Website for the Dual Master Degree in Social work with the College of Health and Human Services |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Peace Corps Master's International{{cite web|url=http://www.peacecorps.gov/volunteer/learn/whyvol/eduben/univandprog/10590/|title=Peace Corps Website for the Master's International Program|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2014-06-18}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Research and practice centers == *[[Center for World Religions, Diplomacy and Conflict Resolution]] *Center for Peacemaking Practice{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/cpp |title=Website for the Center for Peacemaking Practice |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Center for the Study of Gender and Conflict Resolution{{cite web|url=http://scarcgc.wordpress.com/ |title=Website for the Center for the Study of Gender and Conflict |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Center Study of Narrative and Conflict Resolution{{cite web|url=http://cncr.gmu.edu |title=Website for the Center for the Study of Narrative and Conflict Resolution |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} == Programs and projects == {{Div col}} *Program on History and Memory *Program on Ethics and Conflict Resolution *The Political Economy of Civil War and Peacebuilding *Undergraduate Experiential Learning Program{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/experientiallearningproject/home |title=Website for the Undergraduate Experiential Learning Project |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Insight Conflict Resolution Program{{cite web|url=http://www.insightconflictresolution.org |title=Website for the Insight Conflict Resolution Program |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Parents of the Field Project{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/parents |title=Website for the Parents of the Field Project |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Dialogue and Difference *Love and Forgiveness in Governance{{cite web|url=http://blogs.shu.edu/diplomacyresearch/ |title=Seton Hall University Website for Love and Forgiveness in Governance |publisher=[[Seton Hall University]] |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}}{{cite web|url=http://newsdesk.gmu.edu/2013/02/do-love-and-forgiveness-have-a-place-in-government/ |title=Do Love and Forgiveness Have a Place in Government? |publisher=George Mason University News |date=2013-02-27 |accessdate=2014-06-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondintractability.org/lfg |title=Beyond Intractability Website for Love and Forgiveness in Governance |publisher=beyondintractability.org |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Zones of Peace Survey{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/zones-of-peace/home |title=Website for Zones of Peace Survey |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *[[Genocide Prevention]] Program{{cite web|url=http://www.genprev.net |title=Gen Prev Net: Website for the Genocide Prevention Program |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Genocide Watch{{cite web|url=http://www.genocidewatch.org |title=Website for Genocide Watch |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2014-06-18}} *Sudan Task Group {{div col end}} == Notable alumni == *[[Mohammed Abu-Nimer]], expert on conflict resolution and dialog for peace. Professor at the American University School of International Service *[[Chad Ford]], ESPN sports journalist and Assistant Professor at [[Brigham Young University – Hawaii]] (BYUH) *[[Deborah Hersman]], former chair of the U.S. [[National Transportation Safety Board]] *[[Alma Jadallah]], national and international conflict resolution practitioner and scholar, President and Managing Director of Kommon Denominator, Inc. *[[January Makamba]], Tanzanian politician and member of Parliament for Bumbuli constituency, Deputy Minister of Communication, Science and Technology == Current faculty == {{Div col}} *[[Kevin Avruch]] - Henry Hart Rice Professor of Conflict Resolution and Professor of Anthropology and Dean of S-CAR *Sandra Cheldelin - Vernon M. and Minnie I. Lynch Professor of Conflict Resolution *Sara Cobb - Drucie French Cumbie Professor of Conflict Analysis and Resolution *Leslie Dwyer *Thomas Flores *[[Marc Gopin]] - James H. Laue Professor of World Religions, Diplomacy and Conflict Resolution *[[Susan Hirsch]] - Professor of Conflict Resolution and Anthropology *Howon Jeong *Karina Korostelina *Terrence Lyons *[[Christopher Mitchell (anthropologist)|Christopher Mitchell]] - Professor Emeritus of Conflict Analysis and Resolution *Agnieszka Paczynska *Dan Rothbart *Arthur Romano *[[Richard E. Rubenstein]] - University Professor of Conflict Resolution and Public Affairs *Dennis Sandole - Professor of Conflict Resolution and International Relations *Solon Simmons *Julie Shedd - Associate Dean of S-CAR {{div col end}} == Past faculty == {{Div col}} * Henry C. Barringer – U.S. Foreign Service Officer (Ret){{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/newsletter-subject/memoriam-henry-c-barringer-personal-reflection |title=In Memoriam Henry C. Barringer: A Personal Reflection |publisher=S-CAR News, Volume 3, Issue 1 |date=March 2009 | accessdate=2014-07-01}}{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/newsletter-subject/memoriam-henry-c-barringer-personal-reflection |title=A History of George Mason University: 1978-1996: Emergence The School of Conflict Analysis and Resolution |publisher=George Mason University Libraries |date= |accessdate=2014-07-01}} * Andrea Bartoli – Dean of the [[School of Diplomacy and International Relations]] at [[Seton Hall University]] * Ben Broom * [[John Burton (diplomat)|John Burton]] – Former head of the Australian Foreign Office and founder of the Conflict Resolution Program at the University of London{{cite web|url=http://scar.gmu.edu/newsletter-subject/memoriam-henry-c-barringer-personal-reflection |title=A History of George Mason University: 1978-1996: Emergence The School of Conflict Analysis and Resolution |publisher=George Mason University Libraries |date= |accessdate=2014-07-01}} * Mary E. Clark – former Drucie French Cumbie Chair in Conflict Resolution at George Mason University * [[Kevin P. Clements]] – Professor of Peace and Conflict Studies at the [[University of Otago]], New Zealand * Dan Druckman{{Citation needed|date=June 2016}} * Joe Gittler{{Citation needed|date=June 2016}} * James H. Laue (1937–1993) – former Professor of Conflict Resolution and served on the U.S. Department of Justice's Community Relations Service (CRS){{cite web|url=http://sca.gmu.edu/finding_aids/laue.html |title=Guide to the James H. Laue papers, 1936-1999 |publisher=George Mason University Libraries Special Collections and Archives |date= |accessdate=2014-06-14}} * Michelle LeBaron * Tamra Pearson D'stree * Joe Scimecca{{Citation needed|date=June 2016}} * Wallace Warfield (1938–2010) – Professor of Conflict Analysis and Resolution, community mediator and acting director of the U.S. Department of Justice's New York Community Relations Service * Bryant Wedge – Social psychiatrist, first director of CCR, worked for the State Department and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency * Tom Williams{{Citation needed|date=June 2016}} * [[Nadim Rouhana]] – Former Henry Hart Rice Professor of Conflict Resolution and Analysis {{cite web |url=http://scar.gmu.edu/people/nadim-rouhana |title=The School for Conflict Analysis and Resolution, George Mason University, People |accessdate=2016-06-19 }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{div col end}} == Distinguished fellows, visiting scholars and lecturers == *[[Elise M. Boulding]] *[[Kenneth E. Boulding]] *Ron Fisher *[[Johan Galtung]] *[[Herbert Kelman]] *Debra Kolb *Dean Pruitt *[[Anatol Rapoport]] *Peter Wallensteen ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://scar.gmu.edu}} *[http://gmu.edu George Mason University] {{George Mason University}} [[Category:George Mason University]] [[Category:Education in Fairfax County, Virginia]] [[Category:Education in Arlington County, Virginia]] [[Category:Peace and conflict studies]] [[Category:Peace education]] [[Category:Dispute resolution]] [[Category:Conflict (process)]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Virginia]]

revision.text:
{{about|the term|the album by John Zorn|Simulacrum (album)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}}
A '''simulacrum''' ([[plural]]: '''simulacra''' from {{lang-la|simulacrum}}, which means "likeness, similarity") is a representation or imitation of a person or thing.<ref>{{cite web |title=Word of the Day |date=1 May 2003 |publisher=dictionary.com |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/wordoftheday/archive/2003/05/01.html |accessdate=2 May 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070217130815/http://dictionary.reference.com/wordoftheday/archive/2003/05/01.html |archivedate=17 February 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The word was first recorded in the English language in the late 16th century, used to describe a representation, such as a statue or a painting, especially of a god. By the late 19th century, it had gathered a secondary association of inferiority: an image without the substance or qualities of the original.<ref>"simulacrum" ''The New Shorter Oxford English Dictionary'' 1993</ref> Philosopher [[Fredric Jameson]] offers [[photorealism]] as an example of artistic simulacrum, where a painting is sometimes created by copying a photograph that is itself a copy of the real.<ref name="anu.edu.au">Massumi, Brian. [http://www.anu.edu.au/hrc/first_and_last/works/realer.htm "Realer than Real: The Simulacrum According to Deleuze and Guattari."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523090754/http://www.anu.edu.au/hrc/first_and_last/works/realer.htm |date=23 May 2010 }} retrieved 2 May 2007</ref> Other art forms that play with simulacra include [[trompe-l'œil]],<ref>Baudrillard, Jean. ''Simulacra and Simulations.'' transl. Sheila Faria Glaser. [http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/simulacra-and-simulations-xi-holograms/ "XI. Holograms."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527153531/http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/simulacra-and-simulations-xi-holograms/ |date=27 May 2010 }} retrieved 5 May 2010</ref> [[Pop Art|pop art]], [[Italian neorealism]], and [[French New Wave]].<ref name="anu.edu.au" />
==Philosophy== Simulacra have long been of interest to philosophers. In his ''[[Sophist (dialogue)|Sophist]]'', [[Plato]] speaks of two kinds of image making. The first is a faithful reproduction, attempted to copy precisely the original. The second is intentionally distorted in order to make the copy appear correct to viewers. He gives the example of [[Art in ancient Greece|Greek statuary]], which was crafted larger on the top than on the bottom so that viewers on the ground would see it correctly. If they could view it in scale, they would realize it was malformed. This example from the visual arts serves as a [[metaphor]] for the philosophical arts and the tendency of some philosophers to distort truth so that it appears accurate unless viewed from the proper angle.<ref>{{cite book |author=Plato |title=The Sophist |others=Translated by Benjamin Jowett |url=http://philosophy.eserver.org/plato/sophist.txt |accessdate=2 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051230161511/http://philosophy.eserver.org/plato/sophist.txt |archivedate=30 December 2005 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]] addresses the concept of simulacrum (but does not use the term) in the ''[[Twilight of the Idols]]'', suggesting that most philosophers, by ignoring the reliable input of their senses and resorting to the constructs of language and reason, arrive at a distorted copy of reality.<ref>{{cite book |last=Nietzsche |first=Friedrich |chapter=Reason in Philosophy |title=Twilight of the Idols |others=Translated by Walter Kaufmann and R. J. Hollingdale |year=1888 |url=http://www.handprint.com/SC/NIE/GotDamer.html#sect3 |accessdate=2 May 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426104633/http://www.handprint.com/SC/NIE/GotDamer.html#sect3 |archivedate=26 April 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Postmodernism/Philosophy|Postmodernist]] French [[social theorist]] [[Jean Baudrillard]] argues that a simulacrum is not a copy of the real, but becomes truth in its own right: the [[Hyperreality|hyperreal]]. Where Plato saw two types of representation—faithful and intentionally distorted (simulacrum)—Baudrillard sees four: (1) basic reflection of reality; (2) perversion of reality; (3) pretence of reality (where there is no model); and (4) simulacrum, which "bears no relation to any reality whatsoever".<ref name="Simulacra and Simulations">[http://www.stanford.edu/dept/HPS/Baudrillard/Baudrillard_Simulacra.html Baudrillard Simulacra] retrieved 2 May 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040209024621/http://www.stanford.edu/dept/HPS/Baudrillard/Baudrillard_Simulacra.html |date=9 February 2004 }}</ref> In Baudrillard's concept, like Nietzsche's, simulacra are perceived as negative, but another modern philosopher who addressed the topic, [[Gilles Deleuze]], takes a different view, seeing simulacra as the avenue by which an accepted [[Ideal (ethics)|ideal]] or "privileged position" could be "challenged and overturned".<ref>{{cite book |last=Deleuze |first=Gilles |title=Difference and Repetition |others=Translated by Paul Patton |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=Columbia |year=1968 |pages=69}}</ref> Deleuze defines simulacra as "those systems in which different relates to different ''by means of'' difference itself. What is essential is that we find in these systems no ''prior [[Identity (philosophy)|identity]]'', no ''internal resemblance''".<ref>p. 299.</ref>
[[Alain Badiou]], in speaking with reference to Nazism about Evil, writes,<ref>{{cite book |last=Badiou |first=Alain |title=Ethics - An Essay on the Understanding of Evil|others=Translated by Peter Hallward |publisher=Verso |location=London |year=2001 |pages=74}}</ref> "fidelity to a simulacrum, unlike fidelity to an event, regulates its break with the situation not by the universality of the void, but by the closed particularity of an abstract set ... (the 'Germans' or the 'Aryans')".
==Recreation== Recreational simulacra include [[historical reenactment|reenactments of historical events]] or replicas of landmarks, such as [[Colonial Williamsburg]] and the [[Eiffel Tower]], and constructions of fictional or cultural ideas, such as [[Fantasyland]] at [[The Walt Disney Company]]'s [[Magic Kingdom]]. The various Disney parks have by some philosophers been regarded as the ultimate recreational simulacra, with Baudrillard noting that [[Walt Disney World Resort]] is a copy of a copy, "a simulacrum to the second power".<ref>Baudrillard, Jean. transl. Francois Debrix. Liberation. 4 March 1996. [http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/disneyworld-company/ "Disneyworld Company."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527152759/http://www.egs.edu/faculty/jean-baudrillard/articles/disneyworld-company/ |date=27 May 2010 }} retrieved 5 May 2010.</ref> In 1975, Italian author [[Umberto Eco]] argued that at Disney's parks, "we not only enjoy a perfect imitation, we also enjoy the conviction that imitation has reached its apex and afterwards reality will always be inferior to it".<ref>Eco, Umberto. ''Travels in Hyperreality.'' Reproduced in relevant portion at [http://www.acsu.buffalo.edu/~breslin/eco_robots.html "The City of Robots"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060912200642/http://www.acsu.buffalo.edu/~breslin/eco_robots.html |date=12 September 2006 }} retrieved 2 May 2007</ref> This is for some an ongoing concern. Examining the impact of Disney's simulacrum of [[national park]]s, [[Disney's Wilderness Lodge]], environmentalist Jennifer Cypher and [[anthropologist]] Eric Higgs expressed worry that "the boundary between artificiality and reality will become so thin that the artificial will become the centre of moral value".<ref>Cypher, Jennifer and Eric Higgs. [http://www.ethics.ubc.ca/papers/invited/cypher-higgs.html "Colonizing the Imagination: Disney's Wilderness Lodge".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704185846/http://www.ethics.ubc.ca/papers/invited/cypher-higgs.html |date=4 July 2007 }} retrieved 2 May 2007</ref> Eco also refers to commentary on watching sports as sports to the power of three, or sports cubed. First, there are the players who participate in the sport (the real), then the onlookers merely witnessing it, and finally the commentary on the act of witnessing the sport. Visual artist [[Paul McCarthy]] has created entire installations based on ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' and theme park simulacra, with videos playing inside the installation.
==Caricature== An interesting example of simulacrum is [[caricature]]. When an artist produces a line drawing that closely approximates the facial features of a real person, the subject of the sketch cannot be easily identified by a random observer; it can be taken for a likeness of any individual. However, a caricaturist exaggerates prominent facial features, and a viewer will pick up on these features and be able to identify the subject, even though the caricature bears far less actual resemblance to the subject.
==Iconography== Beer (1999: p. 11) employs the term "simulacrum" to denote the formation of a sign or iconographic image, whether [[iconic]] or [[aniconic]], in the landscape or greater field of [[Thangka]] art and Tantric Buddhist [[iconography]]. For example, an iconographic [[Representation (arts)|representation]] of a cloud formation sheltering a deity in a thanka or covering the auspice of a [[sacred mountain]] in the natural environment may be discerned as a simulacrum of an "auspicious canopy" (Sanskrit: [[Chhatra]]) of the [[Ashtamangala]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Beer |first=Robert |year=1999 |title=The Encyclopedia of Tibetan Symbols and Motifs |publisher=Shambhala Publications |isbn=978-1-57062-416-2 |page=11}}</ref> [[Perceptions of religious imagery in natural phenomena]] approach a [[cultural universal]] and may be proffered as evidence of the natural creative spiritual engagement of the experienced environment endemic to the [[human psychology]].
==Word usage== The Latinised plural ''simulacra'' is interchangeable with the anglicised version ''simulacrums''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/simulacrum |title=simulacrum |publisher=Merriam-Webster |accessdate=12 April 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712155454/http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/simulacrum |archivedate=12 July 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Memetics]] * ''[[Simulacra and Simulation]]'' * [[Simulated reality]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{wiktionary}} * [http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/backissues/55/baudrillard55art.htm "Two Essays: Simulacra and Science Fiction; Ballard’s ''Crash''"] Baudrillard, Jean * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070401234222/http://www.cinestatic.com/trans-mat/Fisher/FC3s2.htm "The Simulacrum's Revenge," sec 3.2 of ''Flatline Constructs: Gothic and Cybernetic-Theory Fiction''] Fisher, Mark

{{about|clothing for sports|fashionable clothing identified and marketed as 'sportswear'|Sportswear (fashion)}} {{refimprove|date=August 2013}} [[File:Brooke Sweat and Jennifer Fopma at Hermosa Beach 2012 (2) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|US women's [[beach volleyball]] team has cited several advantages to bikini uniforms, such as comfort while playing on sand during hot weather.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ijr.com/2016/08/670528-heres-why-the-usa-womens-volleyball-team-refuses-to-stop-wearing-bikinis/|title=Here's Why the USA Women’s Volleyball Team Refuses to Stop Wearing Bikinis|date=August 11, 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Photo shows US beach volleyball players [[Jennifer Fopma]] and [[Brooke Sweat]] in their uniforms.]]
'''Sportswear''' or '''activewear''' is [[clothing#Sport and activity|clothing]], including [[footwear#Shoes|footwear]], worn for [[sport]] or [[physical exercise]]. Or it can be a crop top.
Sport-specific clothing is worn for most sports and physical exercise, for practical, comfort or safety reasons.
Typical sport-specific garments include [[tracksuit]]s, [[shorts]], [[T-shirt]]s and [[polo shirt]]s. Specialized garments include [[swimsuit#Competitive swimwear|swimsuits]] (for [[human swimming|swimming]]), [[wet suit]]s (for [[Underwater diving|diving]] or [[surfing]]), [[ski suit]]s (for [[skiing]]) and [[leotards]] (for [[gymnastics]]). Sports footwear include [[athletic shoe|trainers]], [[football boot]]s, [[riding boot]]s, and [[ice skate]]s. Sportswear also includes [[bikini]] and some [[crop tops]] and [[undergarments]], such as the [[jockstrap]] and [[sports bra]]. Sportswear is also at times worn as [[casual attire|casual]] [[fashion]] clothing.
For most sports the athletes wear a combination of different items of clothing, e.g. [[sport shoe]]s, [[trousers|pants]] and [[shirt]]s. In some sports, protective gear may need to be worn, such as [[helmet]]s or [[American football]] body armour.
Sports fabrics are technical materials which help to keep the wearer comfortable during exercise. The type of fabric required will depend upon the intensity of the exercise and the activity. [[Yoga pants|Yoga clothing]] should use fabrics with good stretch ability for easy movement which will likely require the fabric to be of a knitted construction. Apparel for long distance running will keep the wearer in good comfort if it has excellent moisture wicking properties to enable sweat to transfer from the inside to the outside for the garment. Performance clothing for outdoor sports in the winter or snow sports ought to use breathable fabrics with very good insulating properties.
==Functional considerations== [[File:Messi FC BARCELONA - ARSENAL 8 MAR 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|Male football players of opposite teams wearing different colour outfits, while the referee is in white T-shirt.]]
Sportswear is typically designed to be lightweight so as not to encumber the wearer. The best athletic wear for some forms of exercise, for example [[cycling]], should not create drag or be too bulky.
On the other hand, sportswear should be loose enough so as not to restrict movement. Some sports have specific style requirements, for example the [[keikogi]] used in [[karate]]. Various physically dangerous sports require protective gear, e.g. for fencing, American football, or ice hockey.
Standardized sportswear may also function as a uniform. In team sports the opposing sides are usually identified by the colors of their clothing, while individual team members can be recognized by a back number on a shirt.
In some sports, specific items of clothing are worn to differentiate roles within a team. For example, in [[volleyball]], the [[volleyball#libero|libero]] (a specialist in defensive play) wears a different colour to that of their teammates. In sports such as [[soccer]] and [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] codes, a contrasting colour or pattern is worn by the goalkeeper. In other sports, clothing may indicate the current status or past achievements of a participant. In cycling disciplines, the [[rainbow jersey]] indicates the current world champion, and in major road cycling races, [[cycling jersey|jersey]]s of particular colours are worn by the race leader and leaders of auxiliary classifications.
[[Spandex]] is the preferred material for [[form-fitting]] sportswear, such as used in wrestling, [[track & field]], dance, gymnastics, [[speed skating]], and [[Human swimming|swimming]].
Sportswear is commonly used as a means for the promotion of sponsors of a sportsperson or team. In some sports, there are regulations limiting the size or design of sponsorship brand names and logos on items of clothing.
==Thermal properties== Sportswear design must consider the [[thermal insulation]] needs of the wearer. In hot situations, sportswear should allow the wearer to stay cool; while in cold situations, sportswear should help the wearer to stay warm.
Sportswear should also be able to transfer sweat away from the skin, using, for example, moisture transferring fabric. [[Spandex]] is a popular material used as base layers to soak up sweat. For example, in activities such as [[skiing]] and [[mountain climbing]] this is achieved by using layering: moisture transferring (wicking) materials are worn next to the skin, followed by an insulating layer, and then wind and water resistant shell garments.
==Moisture-wicking fabrics== [[File:MoistureTransferringFabric.jpg|thumb|left|Moisture transferring fabric]] Moisture-wicking fabrics are a class of hi-tech fabrics that provide moisture control for an athlete's skin. They move perspiration away from the body to the fabric's outer surface where it can evaporate. These fabrics typically are soft, lightweight, and stretchy—in other words, they are perfectly suited for making activewear. Moisture-wicking means that the fabric is absorbent and this can leave a barrier of wet fabric on your skin. Drywicking is the newest variation of moisture wicking. It is a smart two tier fabric that breaks the surface tension of sweat and propels it through the hydrophobic layer into a natural wicking outer layer like cotton where it is assisted by evaporative cooling leaving your skin absolutely dry. Besides the fact that your body can perform better, it will chemically free prevent odors because a bacteria microclimate cannot grow on dry skin. This broad category of fabrics is used to make garments like T-shirts, sports bras, running and cycling jerseys, socks, tracksuits, and polo-style shirts for any physical activity where the goal is to keep your skin as cool and dry as possible. Moisture-wicking fabrics are used to make apparel for outdoor activities such as hiking, fishing, mountain biking, snow skiing, and mountain climbing. Due to the popularity of garments made from these fabrics, more variations are being introduced to the market.
==Golf attire== Golf has a long tradition of specialized attire—attire that reflects the tradition of Scottish aristocrats taking in fresh air while walking around the golf course, swinging their golf clubs, and exercising in a refined, genteel sort of way. Golf attire though, is also being influenced by modern fabrics and trends that stress function and durability. Golfers, like athletes in other sports, are athletes first, and public figures second. Athletes in all sports are showing a preference for moisture-wicking fabrics, crisp details, and modern fashionable colors.
==Sales trends for activewear== [[File:Keeping Fit and Connected (6635665267) (cropped).jpg|thumb|A woman wearing [[sports bra]] and [[boyshorts]], which were conventionally women's sportswear but are now also worn as [[Casual attire|casuals]] or [[athleisure]] by women in the West.]]
As activewear becomes more fashionable and more popular with consumers, sales have increased. Total U.S. sales of men's and women's activewear rose by 3.2% in the 12 months ending in March 2011 compared with the previous period, to $48.6 billion, according to consumer tracking firm NPD Group Inc.<ref name=crainsnewyork1>{{cite web|last=Pasquarelli|first=Adrianne|title=Activewear makes it onto the runway|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20110710/SUB/307109990|work=Crain's New York Business|accessdate=26 October 2013|date=10 July 2011}}</ref> For all of 2011, activewear sales increased 6.7% from 2010, compared with women's apparel gains in 2011 of 3.1%, also according to NPD Group.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.southbendtribune.com/2012-10-15/business/34479799_1_lululemon-athletica-sales-associates-chicago-marathon |title=Activewear sales up - South Bend Tribune |publisher=Articles.southbendtribune.com |date=2012-10-15 |accessdate=2013-08-17}}</ref>
Some analysts attribute the growth in sales to an intrinsic change in the way activewear is designed. “Historically, what had been available to women were items based on a men's item that were just made smaller and turned a flattering color like pink,” said Scott Key, senior vice president and general manager of Athleta. “Women athletes expected more.” <ref name="crainsnewyork1"/> Designers have recognized this "crossover" between exercise and fashion as a major opportunity for growth. It also syncs nicely with the overall trend in American fashion towards a more casual style of dress. The trend has been so popular that it has spawned a new category of casual clothing, [[athleisure]]. [[Rebecca Minkoff]] is one of the fashion designers who has an entire collection designed around the athleisure concept.
== Protective wear == [[File:US Navy 031230-N-9693M-001 A pair of Navy helmets lays on the field prior to the EV1.Net Houston Bowl at Reliant Stadium in Houston, Texas.jpg|thumb|U.S. Navy [[football helmet]]s]] Sportswear also includes the variety of protective gear required for contact sports such as lacrosse, boxing and ice hockey. Different types of protective equipment are needed depending on the type of sport and position. The types of gears include the following: head gear, gum shields, shin pads, shoulder pads, and joint supports.
=== Head gear === [[File:Tendulkar batting against Australia, October 2010 (1), cropped.jpg|thumb|[[Sachin Tendulkar]] wears traditional [[cricket whites]], together with [[pads]] to protect his legs. Both he and the short leg fielder wear [[cricket helmet]]s for protection.]]
Head gear is required for most sports with high risk of head injuries such as [[American football]], [[Bobsleigh|bobsledding]] and [[cycling]]. Injuries related to the head have the potential to cause serious damage to the spine and may be life-threatening.<ref name="nsmi2">Protective wear during sport - sports injury prevention. Retrieved March 17, 2016, from Sports Medicine Information, http://www.nsmi.org.uk/articles/injury-prevention/protective-wear.html</ref> Although sports like rugby and boxing do not require participants to wear head protection, trainers or referees may choose to depending on the player’s history of head related injuries.<ref name="nsmi2" /> Certain positions of some sports may require different type of protections. For example, goaltenders for ice hockey wear different types of face masks compared to other positions.<ref name=":02">Helmets: How they work and what standards do. Retrieved March 17, 2016, from http://www.helmets.org/general.htm</ref> They also have thick gloves with arm pads and shin guards to protect them from the high impact of pucks. In baseball, catchers and batters wear head gear for protection against the high velocity pitches. Head gear of different kinds must meet the standards of protection set by various organizations. [[Helmet]]s for American football must be regulated by the National Football League or the National Collegiate Athletics Association. Although new rules of safe play have been in effect, players are still in danger of brain damage due to repeated blows to the head.<ref name="nsmi2" /> Football players are more likely to develop brain related disorders during or after their careers compared to other sports.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/01/health/study-focuses-on-repeated-hits-not-concussions.html|title=Study Focuses on Repeated Hits, Not Concussions|last=Carey|first=Benedict|date=2016-03-31|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-04-12}}</ref>
=== Eye and face shields === Sports of all types may require eye or face protection depending on the players’ need. Face masks come in different forms for different types of sports. In lacrosse and American football, the masks are metal rods attached to the helmet to cover the face.<ref name=":02" /> While optional, face masks that might be seen in basketball or rugby are plastic masks that are usually molded to fit the players’ face.<ref>Protective eyewear for young athletes - 2013 (2013). American Academy of Ophthalmology. Retrieved from http://www.aao.org/clinical-statement/protective-eyewear-young-athletes--november-2003</ref> Such masks are worn to minimize additional damage to an already injured part of the face.
Eye protection is an additional support provided by sports goggles. Goggles may be worn in lieu of glasses or contacts. Goggles are reliable in the fact that they do not move around while the player is in motion and they protect the eye from foreign objects.<ref>Sports and your eyes. Retrieved March 17, 2016, from National Eye Institute, https://nei.nih.gov/sports</ref> For swimmers and divers, goggles keep the water away from their eyes, thus improving visibility.
=== Mouth guards === Mouth guards are used in many sports including but not limited to: [[rugby football|rugby]], lacrosse, boxing, water polo, ice hockey, American football, basketball, field hockey, and various martial arts.<ref name=":12" /> Mouth guards reduce the risk of sport related dental injuries. Contact or some team sports have a risk of causing injuries related with the mouth, [[jaw]], teeth and oral soft [[Tissue (biology)|tissues]]. Wearing mouth guards are not required in any sports but the players are recommended to.<ref name=":12">Mouthguards. Retrieved March 17, 2016, from American Dental Association, http://www.ada.org/en/member-center/oral-health-topics/mouthguards</ref>
== Snow gear and ski apparel == [[File:Vonn-lindsey 15-12-07 - 007.jpg|thumb|left|Professional USA ski racer [[Lindsey Vonn]] dressed for a race.]] Different types of attire are needed for extreme weather conditions like snow. Thicker coats or jackets, gloves and boots are necessities in the cold. Winter sports such as snowboarding and skiing require the riders and skiers to be properly geared in the snow. Snow jackets differ from casual coats such that they may be packed with extra insulation and thicker coating materials.<ref name="berry2" /> The insulation is usually made with down, which is the layer of fine feathers from geese or ducks.<ref name="berry2">Berry, G. (2011, December 28). A guide to insulated winter jackets that are not made with down. Retrieved March 17, 2016, from One Green Planet, http://www.onegreenplanet.org/lifestyle/a-guide-to-insulated-winter-jackets-that-are-not-made-with-down/</ref> These feathers are naturally insulated to keep the birds warm in the harsh winter weathers. The feathers trap air inside and keep the body heat from flowing out.<ref name="berry2" /> Down is also considered to be the highest quality of insulation for jackets. It is light and compressible. Alternative types of insulation are being invented including: synthetic microfibers and polyester-based insulation.<ref name="berry2" /> These materials perform as well as down if not better and are becoming popular in the markets with the help of major brands using such materials for their equipment.
Winter gear must also be flexible so that it may offer a wide range of movement. An ideal jacket would have enough insulation to be warm but light, it should be made with material that are not restricting.<ref name="porter2">Porter, J. (2016). How to choose the best ski jacket. Retrieved March 31, 2016, from http://www.outdoorgearlab.com/Ski-Jacket-Reviews/Buying-Advice</ref> Jackets with down will be light and warm but they tend to be more expensive. Also down jackets usually are not water-resistant. Synthetic insulated jackets, however, are water-resistant and cheaper than down but lose their insulating factors and are heavier.<ref name="porter2" />
In the [[Olympic Games|Olympics]], the variety of equipment used contain materials such as aluminum, fiberglass, mineral-based fibers and specialty steel alloys. Skis and snowboards are made up of carbon-fiber, aluminum, titanium and boron-fiber with tungsten alloys. Boots are made with ceramic fibers and steel.<ref>Olympics 2014: Let the Science Begin! Retrieved March 31, 2016, from United States Geological Survey, http://www.usgs.gov/blogs/features/usgs_top_story/olympics-2014-let-the-science-begin/</ref>

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Smasongarrison|Smasongarrison]])
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}}
'''Stuxnet''' is a [[Malware|malicious]] [[computer worm]], first uncovered in 2010. Thought to have been in development since at least 2005, Stuxnet targets [[SCADA]] systems and is believed to be responsible for causing substantial damage to [[Iran's nuclear program]]. Although neither country has openly admitted responsibility, the worm is believed to be a jointly built [[United States|American]]/[[Israel]]i [[cyberweapon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2012/06/confirmed-us-israel-created-stuxnet-lost-control-of-it/|title=Confirmed: US and Israel created Stuxnet, lost control of it|work=Ars Technica}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/stuxnet-was-work-of-us-and-israeli-experts-officials-say/2012/06/01/gJQAlnEy6U_story.html|title=Stuxnet was work of U.S. and Israeli experts, officials say|author=Ellen Nakashima|date=2 June 2012|work=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref>
Stuxnet specifically targets [[programmable logic controller]]s (PLCs), which allow the automation of electromechanical processes such as those used to control machinery on factory assembly lines, amusement rides, or [[Laboratory centrifuge|centrifuges]] for separating nuclear material. Exploiting four [[Zero-day attack|zero-day flaws]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/security/stuxnet-attackers-used-4-windows-zero-day-exploits/7347 |title=Stuxnet attackers used 4 Windows zero-day exploits|publisher=[[ZDNet]]|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> Stuxnet functions by targeting machines using the [[Microsoft Windows]] operating system and networks, then seeking out [[Siemens]] Step7 software. Stuxnet reportedly compromised Iranian PLCs, collecting information on industrial systems and causing the fast-spinning centrifuges to tear themselves apart.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kushner|first=David|title=The Real Story of Stuxnet|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/telecom/security/the-real-story-of-stuxnet/|work=ieee.org|publisher=IEEE Spectrum|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> Stuxnet’s design and architecture are not domain-specific and it could be tailored as a platform for attacking modern [[supervisory control and data acquisition|supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA)]] and PLC systems (e.g., in factory assembly lines or power plants), the majority of which reside in Europe, [[Japan]] and the US.<ref>S. Karnouskos: "[http://papers.duckdns.org/files/2011_IECON_stuxnet.pdf Stuxnet Worm Impact on Industrial Cyber-Physical System Security]". In: "37th Annual Conference of the IEEE Industrial Electronics Society (IECON 2011), Melbourne, Australia", 7–10 November 2011. Retrieved 20 April 2014.</ref> Stuxnet reportedly ruined almost one fifth of Iran's [[nuclear centrifuge]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/stuxnet-was-far-more-dangerous-than-previous-thought-2013-11 |title=The Stuxnet Attack On Iran's Nuclear Plant Was 'Far More Dangerous' Than Previously Thought|work=Business Insider|date=20 November 2013}}</ref> Targeting industrial control systems, the worm infected over 200,000 computers and caused 1,000 machines to physically degrade.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mac-solutions.net/en/news/129-sheep-dip-your-removable-storage-devices-to-reduce-the-threat-of-cyber-attacks|title=Sheep dip your removable storage devices to reduce the threat of cyber attacks|website=www.mac-solutions.net|accessdate=26 July 2017}}</ref>
Stuxnet has three modules: a [[Computer worm|worm]] that executes all routines related to the main payload of the attack; a [[File shortcut|link file]] that automatically executes the propagated copies of the worm; and a [[rootkit]] component responsible for hiding all malicious files and processes, preventing detection of the presence of Stuxnet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://about-threats.trendmicro.com/us/webattack/54/STUXNET%20Malware%20Targets%20SCADA%20Systems |title=STUXNET Malware Targets SCADA Systems|publisher=Trend Micro|date=January 2012}}</ref> It is typically introduced to the target environment via an infected [[USB flash drive]], thereby crossing any [[Air gap (networking)|air gap]]. The worm then propagates across the network, scanning for Siemens Step7 software on computers controlling a PLC. In the absence of either criterion, Stuxnet becomes dormant inside the computer. If both the conditions are fulfilled, Stuxnet introduces the infected rootkit onto the PLC and Step7 software, modifying the codes and giving unexpected commands to the PLC while returning a loop of normal operations system values feedback to the users.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2011/03/stuxnet-201104|title=A Declaration of Cyber-War|work=Vanity Fair|date=April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/exploring-stuxnet-s-plc-infection-process|title=Exploring Stuxnet’s PLC Infection Process|publisher=Symantec|date=23 January 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, [[Kaspersky Lab]] noted that the [[Equation Group]] had used two of the same zero-day attacks, prior to their use in Stuxnet, and commented that: "the similar type of usage of both exploits together in different computer worms, at around the same time, indicates that the Equation Group and the Stuxnet developers are either the same or working closely together".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://securelist.com/files/2015/02/Equation_group_questions_and_answers.pdf |title=Equation Group Questions and Answers |website=securelist.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217023145/https://securelist.com/files/2015/02/Equation_group_questions_and_answers.pdf |archivedate=17 February 2015}}</ref>
== Discovery == Stuxnet, discovered by Sergey Ulasen, initially spread via Microsoft Windows, and targeted Siemens [[industrial control system]]s. While it is not the first time that hackers have targeted industrial systems,<ref name="Siemans-Cyber">{{cite web|url=http://www.totallyintegratedautomation.com/2010/09/building-a-cyber-secure-plant/|publisher=Siemens|title=Building a Cyber Secure Plant|accessdate=5 December 2010 | date=30 September 2010}}</ref> nor the first publicly known intentional act of [[cyberwarfare]] to be implemented, it is the first discovered [[malware]] that spies on and subverts industrial systems,<ref name=compworld /> and the first to include a [[programmable logic controller]] (PLC) [[rootkit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.virusbulletin.com/conference/vb2010/abstracts/indepth-look-stuxnet|title=Last-minute paper: An indepth look into Stuxnet|publisher=Virus Bulletin}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-11414483|title=Stuxnet worm hits Iran nuclear plant staff computers|publisher=BBC News | date=26 September 2010}}</ref>
The worm initially spreads indiscriminately, but includes a highly specialized malware payload that is designed to target only Siemens [[SCADA|supervisory control and data acquisition]] (SCADA) systems that are configured to control and monitor specific industrial processes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-introduces-first-known-rootkit-scada-devices|title=Stuxnet Introduces the First Known Rootkit for Industrial Control Systems|author=Nicolas Falliere|publisher=Symantec|date=6 August 2010}}</ref><ref name=APtehran>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/09/25/world/middleeast/AP-ML-Iran-Cyber-Attacks.html |title=Iran's Nuclear Agency Trying to Stop Computer Worm |agency=Associated Press |location=Tehran |date=25 September 2010 |accessdate=25 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5t1DCvbet?url=http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/09/25/world/middleeast/AP-ML-Iran-Cyber-Attacks.html?_r=1 |archivedate=25 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Stuxnet infects PLCs by subverting the [[WinCC|Step-7]] software application that is used to reprogram these devices.<ref name="Keizer1">{{cite web|url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/2626009/malware/is-stuxnet-the--best--malware-ever-.html|publisher=[[Infoworld]]|title=Is Stuxnet the 'best' malware ever?|date=16 September 2010|author=Gregg Keizer|accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=RewritingPlaybook>{{cite web|author1=Steven Cherry |author2=with Ralph Langner |title=How Stuxnet Is Rewriting the Cyberterrorism Playbook|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/podcast/telecom/security/how-stuxnet-is-rewriting-the-cyberterrorism-playbook|publisher=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=13 October 2010}}</ref>
Different variants of Stuxnet targeted five Iranian organizations,<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-12465688 | title=Stuxnet Virus Targets and Spread Revealed | date=15 February 2011 | accessdate=17 February 2011 | publisher=BBC News }}</ref> with the probable target widely suspected to be [[Enriched uranium|uranium enrichment]] infrastructure in [[Iran]];<ref name=RewritingPlaybook /><ref name=BBC /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/8021102/Stuxnet-virus-worm-could-be-aimed-at-high-profile-Iranian-targets.html |title=Stuxnet virus: worm 'could be aimed at high-profile Iranian targets' |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=23 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010 |location=London |first=Claudine |last=Beaumont}}</ref> [[Symantec]] noted in August 2010 that 60% of the infected computers worldwide were in Iran.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE68N1OI20100924 | work=Reuters | first=William | last=MacLean|title=UPDATE 2-Cyber attack appears to target Iran-tech firms | date=24 September 2010}}</ref> Siemens stated that the worm has not caused any damage to its customers,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/2515570/network-security/siemens--stuxnet-worm-hit-industrial-systems.html|title=Siemens: Stuxnet worm hit industrial systems|author=ComputerWorld|date=14 September 2010|work=|publisher=Computerworld|accessdate=3 October 2010}}</ref> but the [[Iran]] nuclear program, which uses [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1737|embargoed]] Siemens equipment procured secretly, has been damaged by Stuxnet.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/11/29/world/main7100197.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Iran Confirms Stuxnet Worm Halted Centrifuges | date=29 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes20100929">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/30/world/middleeast/30worm.html?_r=2&pagewanted=2&hpw |title=In a Computer Worm, a Possible Biblical Clue |author1=Ethan Bronner |author2=William J. Broad |lastauthoramp=yes |date=29 September 2010 |work=NYTimes |accessdate=2 October 2010}}{{cite news | url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/et-cetera/Software-smart-bomb-fired-at-Iranian-nuclear-plant-Experts/articleshow/6617686.cms | title=Software smart bomb fired at Iranian nuclear plant: Experts | publisher=Economictimes.indiatimes.com | date=24 September 2010 | accessdate=28 September 2010 }}</ref> Kaspersky Lab concluded that the sophisticated attack could only have been conducted "with nation-state support".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.kaspersky.com/about/news/virus/2010/Kaspersky_Lab_provides_its_insights_on_Stuxnet_worm | location=Russia | work=Kaspersky | title=Kaspersky Lab provides its insights on Stuxnet worm | date=24 September 2010}}</ref> [[F-Secure]]'s chief researcher [[Mikko Hyppönen]], when asked if possible nation-state support was involved, agreed "That's what it would look like, yes".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.f-secure.com/weblog/archives/00002040.html | location=Finland | work=F-Secure | title=Stuxnet Questions and Answers – F-Secure Weblog | date=1 October 2010}}</ref>
In May 2011, the PBS program ''[[Need to Know (PBS)|Need To Know]]'' cited a statement by [[Gary Samore]], White House Coordinator for Arms Control and Weapons of Mass Destruction, in which he said, "we're glad they [the Iranians] are having trouble with their centrifuge machine and that we – the US and its allies – are doing everything we can to make sure that we complicate matters for them", offering "winking acknowledgement" of US involvement in Stuxnet.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/security/video-cracking-the-code-defending-against-the-superweapons-of-the-21st-century-cyberwar/9456/ Gary Samore] speaking at the 10 December 2010 Washington Forum of the [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] in Washington DC, reported by C-Span and contained in the PBS program ''Need to Know'' ([https://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/security/video-cracking-the-code-defending-against-the-superweapons-of-the-21st-century-cyberwar/9456/ "Cracking the code: Defending against the superweapons of the 21st century cyberwar"], 4 minutes into piece)</ref> According to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', a showreel that was played at a retirement party for the head of the [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF), [[Gabi Ashkenazi]], included references to Stuxnet as one of his operational successes as the IDF chief of staff.<ref name=retirement>{{cite news|last=Williams |first=Christopher |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/8326387/Israel-video-shows-Stuxnet-as-one-of-its-successes.html |title=Israel video shows Stuxnet as one of its successes |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=14 February 2012 |location=London}}</ref>
On 1 June 2012, an article in ''The New York Times'' said that Stuxnet is part of a US and Israeli intelligence operation called "[[Operation Olympic Games]]", started under President [[George W. Bush]] and expanded under President [[Barack Obama]].<ref name="sanger2012June">{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/01/world/middleeast/obama-ordered-wave-of-cyberattacks-against-iran.html |title = Obama Order Sped Up Wave of Cyberattacks Against Iran |publisher = The New York Times |date = 1 June 2012 |accessdate =1 June 2012 |first = David E. |last = Sanger | authorlink= David E. Sanger }}</ref>
On 24 July 2012, an article by Chris Matyszczyk from [[CNET]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17852_3-57478515-71/thunderstruck-a-tale-of-malware-ac-dc-and-irans-nukes/|title=Thunderstruck! A tale of malware, AC/DC, and Iran's nukes|last=Matyszczyk|first=Chris|publisher=[[CNET]]|date=24 July 2012|accessdate=8 July 2013}}</ref> reported how the [[Atomic Energy Organization of Iran]] e-mailed [[F-Secure]]'s chief research officer [[Mikko Hyppönen]] to report a new instance of malware.
On 25 December 2012, an Iranian semi-official news agency announced there was a cyberattack by Stuxnet, this time on the industries in the southern area of the country. The virus targeted a power plant and some other industries in [[Hormozgan province]] in recent months.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-20842113|title=Iran 'fends off new Stuxnet cyber attack'|publisher=BBC NEWS|date=25 December 2012|accessdate=28 May 2015}}</ref>
According to expert [[Eugene Kaspersky]], the worm also infected a nuclear power plant in Russia. Kaspersky noted, however, that since the power plant is not connected to the public Internet, the system should remain safe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/stuxnet-gone-rogue-hit-russian-nuke-plant-space-station/|title=Stuxnet, gone rogue, hit Russian nuke plant, space station|work=The Times of Israel|last=Shamah|first=David|date=11 November 2013|accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref>
== History == The worm was at first identified by the security company [[VirusBlokAda]] in mid-June 2010.<ref name="Keizer1" /> Journalist [[Brian Krebs]]'s blog posting on 15 July 2010 was the first widely read report on the worm.<ref name="krebs20100715">{{cite web | url=http://krebsonsecurity.com/2010/07/experts-warn-of-new-windows-shortcut-flaw/ | title=Experts Warn of New Windows Shortcut Flaw | accessdate=3 March 2011 | author=Krebs, Brian | date=17 July 2010 | work=Krebs on Security }}</ref><ref name="gross201104">{{cite web | url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2011/03/stuxnet-201104 | title=A Declaration of Cyber-War | date=April 2011 | last=Gross | first=Michael Joseph | work=Vanity Fair | publisher=Condé Nast }}</ref> The original name given by VirusBlokAda was "Rootkit.Tmphider";<ref>{{cite web|title=Rootkit.TmpHider|url=http://www.wilderssecurity.com/showthread.php?p=1712134#post1712134|work=wilderssecurity.com|publisher=Wilders Security Forums|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> Symantec however called it "W32.Temphid", later changing to "W32.Stuxnet".<ref>{{cite web |last=Shearer |first=Jarrad |title=W32.Stuxnet |date=13 July 2010 |work=symantec.com |publisher=[[Symantec]] |url=http://www.symantec.com/security_response/writeup.jsp?docid=2010-071400-3123-99 |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> Its current name is derived from a combination of some keywords in the software (".stub" and "mrxnet.sys").<ref>{{cite web |last=Zetter |first=Kim |title=How digital detectives deciphered Stuxnet, the most menacing malware in history |date=11 July 2011 |work=arstechnica.com |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2011/07/how-digital-detectives-deciphered-stuxnet-the-most-menacing-malware-in-history/ |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last= Karl |title=Stuxnet opens cracks in Iran nuclear program |work=abc.net.au |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |url=http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2011/10/26/3348123.htm |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> The reason for the discovery at this time is attributed to the virus accidentally spreading beyond its intended target (the [[Natanz]] plant) due to a programming error introduced in an update; this led to the worm spreading to an engineer's computer that had been connected to the centrifuges, and spreading further when the engineer returned home and connected his computer to the internet.<ref name="sanger2012June" />
Kaspersky Lab experts at first estimated that Stuxnet started spreading around March or April 2010,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.securelist.com/en/blog/325/Myrtus_and_Guava_the_epidemic_the_trends_the_numbers |title=Myrtus and Guava: the epidemic, the trends, the numbers |author=Alexander Gostev |date=26 September 2010 |accessdate=22 January 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101113112/http://www.securelist.com/en/blog/325/Myrtus_and_Guava_the_epidemic_the_trends_the_numbers |archive-date=1 January 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> but the first variant of the worm appeared in June 2009.<ref name="Keizer1" /> On 15 July 2010, the day the worm's existence became widely known, a [[distributed denial-of-service]] attack was made on the servers for two leading mailing lists on industrial-systems security. This attack, from an unknown source but likely related to Stuxnet, disabled one of the lists and thereby interrupted an important source of information for power plants and factories.{{r|gross201104}} On the other hand, researchers at [[Symantec]] have uncovered a version of the Stuxnet computer virus that was used to attack Iran's nuclear program in November 2007, being developed as early as 2005, when Iran was still setting up its uranium enrichment facility.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/26/us-cyberwar-stuxnet-idUSBRE91P0PP20130226 | work=Reuters | first=Jim | last=Finkle|title=Researchers say Stuxnet was deployed against Iran in 2007 | date=26 February 2013}}</ref>
The second variant, with substantial improvements, appeared in March 2010, apparently because its authors believed that Stuxnet was not spreading fast enough; a third, with minor improvements, appeared in April 2010.{{r|gross201104}} The worm contains a component with a build time-stamp from 3 February 2010.<ref name="eset_microscope">{{cite web |url=http://go.eset.com/us/resources/white-papers/Stuxnet_Under_the_Microscope.pdf |title=Stuxnet Under the Microscope |format=PDF |author1=Aleksandr Matrosov |author2=Eugene Rodionov |author3=David Harley |author4=Juraj Malcho |last-author-amp=yes |accessdate=24 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011095238/http://go.eset.com/us/resources/white-papers/Stuxnet_Under_the_Microscope.pdf |archivedate=11 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In the United Kingdom on 25 November 2010, [[Sky News]] reported that it had received information from an anonymous source at an unidentified [[IT security]] organization that Stuxnet, or a variation of the worm, had been traded on the [[black market]].<ref name="cyber terrorists">{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Stuxnet-Worm-Virus-Targeted-At-Irans-Nuclear-Plant-Is-In-Hands-Of-Bad-Guys-Sky-News-Sources-Say/Article/201011415827544 |title=Super Virus A Target For Cyber Terrorists |author=Sam Kiley|accessdate=25 November 2010}}</ref>
== Affected countries == A study of the spread of Stuxnet by [[Symantec]] showed that the main affected countries in the early days of the infection were Iran, Indonesia and India:<ref name="W32.Stuxnet">{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/security_response/writeup.jsp?docid=2010-071400-3123-99 |title=W32.Stuxnet|accessdate=2 March 2011 | publisher=[[Symantec]]|date=17 September 2010}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Country ! Share of infected computers |- | Iran | 58.85% |- | Indonesia | 18.22% |- | India | 8.31% |- | Azerbaijan | 2.57% |- | United States | 1.56% |- | Pakistan | 1.28% |- | Other countries | 9.2% |}
Iran was reported to have "beefed up" its cyberwar capabilities following the Stuxnet attack, and has been suspected of retaliatory attacks against US banks.<ref>"[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/23/us-iran-cyberattacks-denial-idUSBRE88M06O20120923 Iran denies hacking into American banks]" Reuters, 23 September 2012</ref>
== Operation == {{rquote|right|[O]ne of the great technical blockbusters in malware history.|''Vanity Fair'', April 2011{{r|gross201104}}}} Unlike most malware, Stuxnet does little harm to computers and networks that do not meet specific configuration requirements; "The attackers took great care to make sure that only their designated targets were hit...
