It was a marksman's job."{{r|broad20110115}} While the worm is promiscuous, it makes itself inert if Siemens software is not found on infected computers, and contains safeguards to prevent each infected computer from spreading the worm to more than three others, and to erase itself on 24 June 2012.{{r|gross201104}}
For its targets, Stuxnet contains, among other things, code for a [[man-in-the-middle attack]] that fakes industrial process control sensor signals so an infected system does not shut down due to detected abnormal behavior.{{r|gross201104}}{{r|broad20110115}}<ref name=SonsOfStuxnet>{{cite web|author1=Steven Cherry |author2=with Larry Constantine |title=Sons of Stuxnet|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/podcast/telecom/security/sons-of-stuxnet|publisher=[[IEEE Spectrum]]|date=14 December 2011}}</ref> Such complexity is very unusual for [[malware]]. The worm consists of a layered attack against three different systems:
# The [[Microsoft Windows|Windows operating system]], # Siemens PCS 7, WinCC and STEP7 industrial software applications that run on Windows and # One or more Siemens S7 PLCs.
=== Windows infection === Stuxnet attacked Windows systems using an unprecedented four [[zero-day attack]]s (plus the [[CPLINK]] [[vulnerability (computing)|vulnerability]] and a vulnerability used by the [[Conficker]] worm<ref>{{cite web|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/security/dd452420.aspx|title=Conficker Worm: Help Protect Windows from Conficker|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|date=10 April 2009|accessdate=6 December 2010}}</ref>). It is initially spread using infected removable drives such as [[USB flash drive]]s,<ref name=RewritingPlaybook /><ref name="eset_microscope" /> which contain Windows shortcut files to initiate executable code.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Alex Buda |title=Creating Malware using the Stuxnet LNK Exploit |url=http://www.rubydevices.com.au/blog/stuxnetLnkExploit|publisher=Ruby Devices|date=4 December 2016}}</ref> The worm then uses other exploits and techniques such as [[peer-to-peer]] [[Remote procedure call|RPC]] to infect and update other computers inside private networks that are not directly connected to the Internet.<ref name=wired /><ref>{{cite web|author=Liam O Murchu|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-p2p-component|title=Stuxnet P2P component|publisher=[[Symantec]]|date=17 September 2010|accessdate=24 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="symantec_dossier" /> The number of zero-day exploits used is unusual, as they are highly valued and [[Hacker (computer security)|malware creators]] do not typically make use of (and thus simultaneously make visible) four different zero-day exploits in the same worm.<ref name=BBC /> Amongst these exploits were remote code execution on a computer with Printer Sharing enabled,<ref>{{cite web|last=Microsoft|title=Microsoft Security Bulletin MS10-061 – Critical|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms10-061.aspx|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|accessdate=20 August 2015|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> and the LNK/PIF vulnerability,<ref>{{cite web|last=Microsoft|title=Microsoft Security Bulletin MS10-046 – Critical|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms10-046.aspx|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|accessdate=20 August 2015|date=2 August 2010}}</ref> in which file execution is accomplished when an icon is viewed in Windows Explorer; negating the need for user interaction.<ref>{{cite web|first=Alexander|last=Gostev|title=Myrtus and Guava, Episode MS10-061|url=https://securelist.com/blog/incidents/29747/myrtus-and-guava-episode-ms10-061/|publisher=[[Kaspersky Lab]]|accessdate=20 August 2015|date=14 September 2010}}</ref> Stuxnet is unusually large at half a megabyte in size,<ref name=wired>{{cite news|author=Kim Zetter |title=Blockbuster Worm Aimed for Infrastructure, But No Proof Iran Nukes Were Target|url=https://www.wired.com/2010/09/stuxnet-2/|publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=23 September 2010 |accessdate=4 November 2016}}</ref> and written in several different programming languages (including [[C (programming language)|C]] and [[C++]]) which is also irregular for malware.<ref name=compworld /><ref name="Keizer1" /><ref name=SonsOfStuxnet /> The Windows component of the malware is [[promiscuous]] in that it spreads relatively quickly and indiscriminately.<ref name="eset_microscope" />
The malware has both [[user-mode]] and [[kernel-mode]] [[rootkit]] capability under Windows,<ref name="symantec_dossier" /> and its [[device driver]]s have been [[digital signature|digitally signed]] with the private keys of two [[public key certificate|certificates]] that were stolen from separate well-known companies, [[JMicron]] and [[Realtek]], both located at [[Hsinchu Science Park]] in Taiwan.<ref name="eset_microscope" /><ref name=wired /> The [[Code signing|driver signing]] helped it install [[Ring (computer security)|kernel-mode]] rootkit drivers successfully without users being notified, and therefore it remained undetected for a relatively long period of time.<ref name=kaspersky>{{cite web|url=http://www.kaspersky.com/about/news/virus/2010/Kaspersky_Lab_provides_its_insights_on_Stuxnet_worm|title=Kaspersky Lab provides its insights on Stuxnet worm |publisher=Kaspersky Lab| date=24 September 2010 |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref> Both compromised certificates have been [[Revocation list|revoked]] by [[Verisign]].
Two websites in Denmark and Malaysia were configured as [[command and control]] servers for the malware, allowing it to be updated, and for [[industrial espionage]] to be conducted by uploading information. Both of these [[domain name]]s have subsequently been redirected by their [[DNS]] service provider to [[Dynadot]] as part of a global effort to disable the malware.<ref name="symantec_dossier" />{{r|gross201104}}
=== Step 7 software infection === [[File:Step7 communicating with plc.svg|thumb|right|Overview of normal communications between Step 7 and a Siemens [[Programmable logic controller|PLC]]]] [[File:Stuxnet modifying plc.svg|thumb|right|Overview of Stuxnet hijacking communication between Step 7 software and a Siemens PLC]] According to researcher [[Ralph Langner]],<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2011/03/stuxnet-201104 | title=A Declaration of Cyber-War | journal=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] | date=April 2011 | author=Michael Joseph Gross | accessdate=4 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.langner.com/en/2010/09/14/ralphs-step-by-step-guide-to-get-a-crack-at-stuxnet-traffic-and-behavior/ | title=Ralph's Step-By-Step Guide to Get a Crack at Stuxnet Traffic and Behaviour | author=[[Ralph Langner]] | date=14 September 2010 | accessdate=4 March 2011 }}</ref> once installed on a Windows system Stuxnet infects project files belonging to Siemens' [[WinCC]]/[[PCS 7]] SCADA control software<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-infection-step-7-projects | title=Stuxnet Infection of Step 7 Projects | author=Nicolas Falliere | publisher=Symantec | date=26 September 2010 }}</ref> (Step 7), and subverts a key communication library of WinCC called <code>s7otbxdx.dll</code>. Doing so intercepts communications between the WinCC software running under Windows and the target Siemens PLC devices that the software is able to configure and program when the two are connected via a data cable. In this way, the malware is able to install itself on PLC devices unnoticed, and subsequently to mask its presence from WinCC if the control software attempts to read an infected block of memory from the PLC system.<ref name="symantec_dossier" />
The malware furthermore used a [[Zero-day (computing)|zero-day exploit]] in the WinCC/SCADA database software in the form of a hard-coded database password.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2010-2772|title=Vulnerability Summary for CVE-2010-2772|date=22 July 2010|accessdate=7 December 2010|publisher=[[National Vulnerability Database]]}}</ref>
=== PLC infection === [[File:S7300.JPG|thumb|left|Siemens Simatic S7-300 PLC CPU with three I/O modules attached]]
The entirety of the Stuxnet code has not yet been disclosed, but its payload targets only those SCADA configurations that meet criteria that it is programmed to identify.{{r|gross201104}}
Stuxnet requires specific slave [[variable-frequency drive]]s (frequency converter drives) to be attached to the targeted Siemens S7-300 system and its associated modules. It only attacks those PLC systems with variable-frequency drives from two specific vendors: [[Vacon]] based in Finland and Fararo Paya based in Iran.<ref name="chien">{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/stuxnet-breakthrough|title=Stuxnet: A Breakthrough|author=Eric Chien|publisher=Symantec|date=12 November 2010|accessdate=14 November 2010}}</ref> Furthermore, it monitors the frequency of the attached motors, and only attacks systems that spin between 807 [[Hertz|Hz]] and 1,210 Hz. The industrial applications of motors with these parameters are diverse, and may include pumps or [[gas centrifuge]]s.
Stuxnet installs malware into memory block DB890 of the PLC that monitors the [[Profibus]] messaging bus of the system.<ref name="symantec_dossier" /> When certain criteria are met, it periodically modifies the frequency to 1,410 Hz and then to 2 Hz and then to 1,064 Hz, and thus affects the operation of the connected motors by changing their rotational speed.<ref name="chien" /> It also installs a rootkit – the first such documented case on this platform – that hides the malware on the system and masks the changes in rotational speed from monitoring systems.
== Removal == Siemens has released a detection and removal tool for Stuxnet. Siemens recommends contacting customer support if an infection is detected and advises installing Microsoft updates for security vulnerabilities and prohibiting the use of third-party [[USB flash drive]]s.<ref name="Siemens">{{cite web|url=http://support.automation.siemens.com/WW/llisapi.dll?func=ll&objid=43876783&nodeid0=10805583&caller=view&lang=en&siteid=cseus&aktprim=0&objaction=csopen&extranet=standard&viewreg=WW#Recommended_procedure%200408|accessdate=24 September 2010|publisher=[[Siemens]]|title=SIMATIC WinCC / SIMATIC PCS 7: Information concerning Malware / Virus / Trojan}}</ref> Siemens also advises immediately upgrading password access codes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20011095-83.html|title=Siemens warns Stuxnet targets of password risk|date=20 July 2010|accessdate=17 September 2010|publisher=[[CNET]]|author=Tom Espiner}}</ref>
The worm's ability to reprogram external PLCs may complicate the removal procedure. Symantec's [[Liam O'Murchu]] warns that fixing Windows systems may not completely solve the infection; a thorough audit of PLCs may be necessary. Despite speculation that incorrect removal of the worm could cause damage,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/205420/siemens_stuxnet_worm_hit_industrial_systems.html|title=Siemens: Stuxnet Worm Hit Industrial Systems|publisher=IDG News}}</ref> Siemens reports that in the first four months since discovery, the malware was successfully removed from the systems of 22 customers without any adverse impact.<ref name="Siemens" /><ref name="crve">{{cite web|url=http://www.h-online.com/security/news/item/Stuxnet-also-found-at-industrial-plants-in-Germany-1081469.html|title=Stuxnet also found at industrial plants in Germany |author=crve|publisher=[[The H]]|date=17 September 2010|accessdate=18 September 2010}}</ref>
== Control system security == {{Main|Control system security}} Prevention of control system security incidents,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.securityincidents.org|accessdate=14 October 2010|publisher=Security Incidents Organization|title=Repository of Industrial Security Incidents}}</ref> such as from viral infections like Stuxnet, is a topic that is being addressed in both the public and the private sector.
The US Department of Homeland Security [[National Cyber Security Division]] (NCSD) operates the Control System Security Program (CSSP).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.us-cert.gov/control_systems/|accessdate=14 October 2010|publisher=[[United States Department of Homeland Security|DHS]]|title=DHS National Cyber Security Division's CSSP}}</ref> The program operates a specialized [[computer emergency response team]] called the [[Industrial Control Systems Cyber Emergency Response Team]] (ICS-CERT), conducts a biannual conference ({{abbr|ICSJWG|Industrial Control Systems Joint Working Group}}), provides training, publishes recommended practices, and provides a self-assessment tool. As part of a Department of Homeland Security plan to improve American computer security, in 2008 it and the [[Idaho National Laboratory]] (INL) worked with Siemens to identify security holes in the company's widely used Process Control System 7 (PCS 7) and its software Step 7. In July 2008, INL and Siemens publicly announced flaws in the control system at a Chicago conference; Stuxnet exploited these holes in 2009.<ref name="broad20110115">{{cite news | last1=Broad | first1=William J. | first2=John | last2=Markoff | first3=David E. | last3=Sanger | title=Israel Tests on Worm Called Crucial in Iran Nuclear Delay | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/16/world/middleeast/16stuxnet.html?_r=1&ref=general&src=me&pagewanted=all | accessdate=16 January 2011 | newspaper=New York Times | date=15 January 2011 }}</ref>
Several industry organizations<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isa.org/MSTemplate.cfm?MicrositeID=988&CommitteeID=6821|accessdate=14 October 2010|publisher=[[International Society of Automation]]|title=ISA99, Industrial Automation and Control System Security}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iec.ch/cgi-bin/procgi.pl/www/iecwww.p?wwwlang=E&wwwprog=pro-det.p&He=IEC&Pu=62443&Pa=2&Se=1&Am=&Fr=&TR=&Ed=1|accessdate=14 October 2010|publisher=[[International Electrotechnical Commission]]|title=Industrial communication networks – Network and system security – Part 2-1: Establishing an industrial automation and control system security program}}</ref> and professional societies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanchemistry.com/s_chemitc/sec_callout.asp?CID=1733&DID=6429|accessdate=14 October 2010|publisher=ACC ChemITC|title=Chemical Sector Cyber Security Program|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019140808/http://americanchemistry.com/s_chemitc/sec_callout.asp?CID=1733&DID=6429|archivedate=19 October 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.api.org/meetings/topics/pipeline/upload/Pipeline_SCADA_Security_Standard.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2010|publisher=[[API]]|title=Pipeline SCADA Security Standard}}</ref> have published standards and best practice guidelines providing direction and guidance for control system end-users on how to establish a [[control system security]] management program. The basic premise that all of these documents share is that prevention requires a multi-layered approach, often referred to as "[[Defense in depth (computing)|defense-in-depth]]".<ref>{{cite conference|title=2008 Automation Summit: A User's Conference|author=Marty Edwards (Idaho National Laboratory) & Todd Stauffer (Siemens)|url=http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/science/NSTB.pdf|page=35|publisher=United States Department of Homeland Security}}</ref> The layers include policies and procedures, awareness and training, network segmentation, access control measures, physical security measures, system hardening, e.g., patch management, and system monitoring, anti-virus and [[intrusion prevention system]] (IPS). The standards and best practices{{who|date=December 2010}} also all{{synthesis inline|date=December 2010}} recommend starting with a risk analysis and a control system security assessment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.controlglobal.com/articles/2010/StuxnetWorm1010.html|accessdate=14 October 2010|publisher=controlglobal.com|title=The Can of Worms Is Open-Now What?}}</ref><ref name="tofinoexida201202">{{cite web | url=http://www.exida.com/index.php/News/new_whitepaper_the_7_steps_to_ics_and_scada_security/ | title=The 7 Steps to ICS Security | accessdate=3 March 2011 | date=16 February 2012 | publisher=Tofino Security and exida Consulting LLC | author1=Byres, Eric | author2=Cusimano, John | lastauthoramp=yes | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123141949/http://www.exida.com/index.php/News/new_whitepaper_the_7_steps_to_ics_and_scada_security/ | archivedate=23 January 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Target and origin == {{Update-section|date=December 2017}} Experts believe that Stuxnet required the largest and costliest development effort in malware history.{{r|gross201104}} Developing its many capabilities would have required a team of highly capable programmers, in-depth knowledge of [[industrial process]]es, and an interest in attacking industrial infrastructure.<ref name=compworld>{{cite web | url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/2515570/network-security/siemens--stuxnet-worm-hit-industrial-systems.html | author=Robert McMillan | date=16 September 2010 | publisher=Computerworld | accessdate=16 September 2010 | title=Siemens: Stuxnet worm hit industrial systems }}</ref><ref name="Keizer1" /> Eric Byres, who has years of experience maintaining and troubleshooting Siemens systems, told ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' that writing the code would have taken many man-months, if not man-years.<ref name="wired" /> [[Symantec]] estimates that the group developing Stuxnet would have consisted of anywhere from five to thirty people, and would have taken six months to prepare.<ref name=guardian>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/sep/24/stuxnet-worm-national-agency| title=Stuxnet worm is the 'work of a national government agency'|date=24 September 2010| accessdate=27 September 2010|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|first=Josh|last=Halliday}}</ref>{{r|gross201104}} ''The Guardian'', the BBC and ''The New York Times'' all claimed that (unnamed) experts studying Stuxnet believe the complexity of the code indicates that only a nation-state would have the capabilities to produce it.<ref name=BBC /><ref name=guardian /><ref name=nyt>{{cite web |last=Markoff |first=John |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/27/technology/27virus.html |title=A Silent Attack, but Not a Subtle One |publisher=New York Times |date=26 September 2010 |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref> The self-destruct and other safeguards within the code implied that a Western government was responsible, or at least is responsible in the development of it.{{r|gross201104}} Software security expert [[Bruce Schneier]] initially condemned the 2010 news coverage of Stuxnet as hype, however, stating that it was almost entirely based on speculation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/10/06/iran-nuclear-computer-technology-security-stuxnet-worm.html | title=The Story Behind The Stuxnet Virus | first=Bruce | last=Schneier | date=6 October 2010 | work=Forbes }}</ref> But after subsequent research, Schneier stated in 2012 that "we can now conclusively link Stuxnet to the centrifuge structure at the Natanz nuclear enrichment lab in Iran".<ref>{{cite web|last=Schneier |first=Bruce |url=http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2012/02/another_piece_o.html |title=Another Piece of the Stuxnet Puzzle |publisher=Schneier on Security |date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=4 March 2012}}</ref>
=== Iran as target === Ralph Langner, the researcher who identified that Stuxnet infected PLCs,<ref name=RewritingPlaybook /> first speculated publicly in September 2010 that the malware was of Israeli origin, and that it targeted Iranian nuclear facilities.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/terrorism-security/2010/1001/Clues-emerge-about-genesis-of-Stuxnet-worm | title=Clues Emerge About Genesis of Stuxnet Worm | last=Bright|first=Arthur | publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] | date=1 October 2010 | accessdate=4 March 2011 }}</ref> However Langner more recently, in a [[TED (conference)|TED Talk]] recorded in February 2011, stated that, "My opinion is that the [[Mossad]] is involved, but that the leading force is not Israel. The leading force behind Stuxnet is the cyber superpower – there is only one; and that's the United States."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ted.com/talks/ralph_langner_cracking_stuxnet_a_21st_century_cyberweapon.html | title=Ralph Langner: Cracking Stuxnet, a 21st-century cyber weapon | last=Langner|first=Ralph | date=February 2011 }}</ref> Kevin Hogan, Senior Director of Security Response at Symantec, reported that the majority of infected systems were in [[Iran]] (about 60%),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/2519584/network-security/iran-was-prime-target-of-scada-worm.html|author=Robert McMillan|date=23 July 2010|title=Iran was prime target of SCADA worm|accessdate=17 September 2010|publisher=[[Computerworld]]}}</ref> which has led to speculation that it may have been deliberately targeting "high-value infrastructure" in Iran<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-11388018|title=Stuxnet worm 'targeted high-value Iranian assets'|publisher=BBC News|date=23 September 2010|accessdate=23 September 2010|last=Fildes|first=Jonathan}}</ref> including either the [[Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant]] or the [[Nuclear facilities in Iran#Natanz|Natanz nuclear facility]].<ref name=wired /><ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Woodward| url=http://warincontext.org/2010/09/26/iran-confirms-stuxnet-found-at-bushehr-nuclear-power-plant/ |title=Iran confirms Stuxnet found at Bushehr nuclear power plant| publisher=Warincontext.org |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2010/09/27/6_mysteries_about_stuxnet |title=6 mysteries about Stuxnet |publisher=Blog.foreignpolicy.com |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> Langner called the malware "a one-shot weapon" and said that the intended target was probably hit,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2010/0921/Stuxnet-malware-is-weapon-out-to-destroy-Iran-s-Bushehr-nuclear-plant|title=Stuxnet malware is 'weapon' out to destroy ... Iran's Bushehr nuclear plant?|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=21 September 2010 |accessdate=23 September 2010|last=Clayton|first=Mark}}</ref> although he admitted this was speculation.<ref name=wired /> Another German researcher and spokesman of the German-based [[Chaos Computer Club]], Frank Rieger, was the first to speculate that Natanz was the target.{{r|gross201104}}
==== Natanz nuclear facilities ==== [[File:Natanz nuclear.jpg|right|thumb|[[Anti-aircraft gun]]s guarding Natanz Nuclear Facility]] {{external media | align = right | width = | image1 = [http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/iran/natanz-imagery.htm Satellite Imagery of the Natanz Enrichment Facility]<ref>{{cite web|last=Pike|first=John|title=Satellite Imagery of the Natanz Enrichment Facility|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/iran/natanz-imagery.htm|work=globalsecurity.org|publisher=GlobalSecurity.org|accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> }} According to the Israeli newspaper ''[[Haaretz]]'', in September 2010 experts on Iran and computer security specialists were increasingly convinced that Stuxnet was meant "to [[sabotage]] the uranium enrichment facility at Natanz – where the centrifuge operational capacity had dropped over the past year by 30 percent."<ref>{{cite web | author=Yossi Melman | url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/computer-virus-in-iran-actually-targeted-larger-nuclear-facility-1.316052 | title='Computer virus in Iran actually targeted larger nuclear facility' | date=28 September 2010 | accessdate=1 January 2011 }}</ref> On 23 November 2010 it was announced that uranium enrichment at Natanz had ceased several times because of a series of major technical problems.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globalsecuritynewswire.org/gsn/nw_20101123_2990.php | title=Iranian Nuclear Program Plagued by Technical Difficulties | publisher=Globalsecuritynewswire.org | date=23 November 2010 | accessdate=24 November 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/iran-pauses-uranium-enrichment-at-natanz-nuclear-plant-1.326276 | title=Iran pauses uranium enrichment at Natanz nuclear plant | publisher=Haaretz.com | date=24 November 2010 | accessdate=24 November 2010 }}</ref> A "serious nuclear accident" (supposedly the shutdown of some of its centrifuges<ref name=economist />) occurred at the site in the first half of 2009, which is speculated to have forced the head of Iran's Atomic Energy Organization [[Gholam Reza Aghazadeh]] to resign.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mirror.wikileaks.info/wiki/Serious_nuclear_accident_may_lay_behind_Iranian_nuke_chief%27s_mystery_resignation |title=Serious nuclear accident may lay behind Iranian nuke chief%27s mystery resignation |publisher=wikileaks |date=16 July 2009 |accessdate=1 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230121529/http://mirror.wikileaks.info/wiki/Serious_nuclear_accident_may_lay_behind_Iranian_nuke_chief's_mystery_resignation/ |archivedate=30 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Statistics published by the [[Federation of American Scientists]] (FAS) show that the number of enrichment centrifuges operational in Iran mysteriously declined from about 4,700 to about 3,900 beginning around the time the nuclear incident WikiLeaks mentioned would have occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isisnucleariran.org/assets/pdf/ISIS_Analysis_IAEA_Report_16Nov2009.pdf |title=IAEA Report on Iran |publisher=[[Institute for Science and International Security]] |date=16 November 2010 |accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Institute for Science and International Security]] (ISIS) suggests, in a report published in December 2010, that Stuxnet is a reasonable explanation for the apparent damage<ref name=ISIS-1>{{cite web|url=http://isis-online.org/uploads/isis-reports/documents/stuxnet_FEP_22Dec2010.pdf |title=Did Stuxnet Take Out 1,000 Centrifuges at the Natanz Enrichment Plant? |publisher=[[Institute for Science and International Security]] |date=22 December 2010 |accessdate=27 December 2010}}</ref> at Natanz, and may have destroyed up to 1,000 centrifuges (10 percent) sometime between November 2009 and late January 2010. The authors conclude:
{{quote|The attacks seem designed to force a change in the centrifuge’s rotor speed, first raising the speed and then lowering it, likely with the intention of inducing excessive vibrations or distortions that would destroy the centrifuge. If its goal was to quickly destroy all the centrifuges in the FEP [Fuel Enrichment Plant], Stuxnet failed. But if the goal was to destroy a more limited number of centrifuges and set back Iran’s progress in operating the FEP, while making detection difficult, it may have succeeded, at least temporarily.<ref name=ISIS-1/>}}
The ISIS report further notes that Iranian authorities have attempted to conceal the breakdown by installing new centrifuges on a large scale.<ref name=ISIS-1/><ref name="Spiege l 26 December 2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/netzpolitik/0,1518,736604,00.html |title=Stuxnet-Virus könnte tausend Uran-Zentrifugen zerstört haben |publisher=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=26 December 2010 |accessdate=27 December 2010}}</ref>
The worm worked by first causing an infected Iranian IR-1 centrifuge to increase from its normal operating speed of 1,064 [[hertz]] to 1,410 hertz for 15 minutes before returning to its normal frequency. Twenty-seven days later, the worm went back into action, slowing the infected centrifuges down to a few hundred hertz for a full 50 minutes. The stresses from the excessive, then slower, speeds caused the aluminium centrifugal tubes to expand, often forcing parts of the centrifuges into sufficient contact with each other to destroy the machine.<ref name="Stark">{{cite news|author=Stark, Holger|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,778912,00.html|title=Mossad's Miracle Weapon: Stuxnet Virus Opens New Era of Cyber War|publisher=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=8 August 2011}}</ref>
According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]] cameras installed in the Natanz facility recorded the sudden dismantling and removal of approximately 900–1,000 centrifuges during the time the Stuxnet worm was reportedly active at the plant. Iranian technicians, however, were able to quickly replace the centrifuges and the report concluded that uranium enrichment was likely only briefly disrupted.<ref>Warrick, Joby, "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/15/AR2011021506501.html Iran's Natanz nuclear facility recovered quickly from Stuxnet cyberattack]", ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 16 February 2011, retrieved 17 February 2011.</ref>
On 15 February 2011, the [[Institute for Science and International Security]] released a report concluding that: {{quote|Assuming Iran exercises caution, Stuxnet is unlikely to destroy more centrifuges at the Natanz plant. Iran likely cleaned the malware from its control systems. To prevent re-infection, Iran will have to exercise special caution since so many computers in Iran contain Stuxnet.
Although Stuxnet appears to be designed to destroy centrifuges at the Natanz facility, destruction was by no means total. Moreover, Stuxnet did not lower the production of [[Enriched uranium#Low-enriched uranium (LEU)|low-enriched uranium (LEU)]] during 2010. LEU quantities could have certainly been greater, and Stuxnet could be an important part of the reason why they did not increase significantly. Nonetheless, there remain important questions about why Stuxnet destroyed only 1,000 centrifuges. One observation is that it may be harder to destroy centrifuges by use of cyber attacks than often believed.<ref name=ISIS-2>{{cite web|url=http://isis-online.org/isis-reports/detail/stuxnet-malware-and-natanz-update-of-isis-december-22-2010-reportsupa-href1/8|title=Stuxnet Malware and Natanz: Update of ISIS December 22, 2010 Report|publisher=[[Institute for Science and International Security]] |date= 15 February 2011}}</ref>}}
==== Iranian reaction ==== The [[Associated Press]] reported that the semi-official [[Iranian Students News Agency]] released a statement on 24 September 2010 stating that experts from the [[Atomic Energy Organization of Iran]] met in the previous week to discuss how Stuxnet could be removed from their systems.<ref name=APtehran /> According to analysts, such as [[David Albright]], [[Western world|Western]] intelligence agencies had been attempting to [[sabotage]] the Iranian nuclear program for some time.<ref name="sabotage">{{cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/iran/signs-of-sabotage-in-tehran-s-nuclear-programme-1.658481|title=Signs of sabotage in Tehran's nuclear programme|publisher=Gulf News|date=14 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120230019/http://gulfnews.com/news/region/iran/signs-of-sabotage-in-tehran-s-nuclear-programme-1.658481|archivedate=20 November 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=EyesCyberwar>{{cite news|author=Dan Williams|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLV83872|title=Wary of naked force, Israel eyes cyberwar on Iran|publisher=Reuters|date=7 July 2009}}</ref>
The head of the Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant told [[Reuters]] that only the [[personal computer]]s of staff at the plant had been infected by Stuxnet and the state-run newspaper ''Iran Daily'' quoted [[Reza Taghipour]], Iran's telecommunications minister, as saying that it had not caused "serious damage to government systems".<ref name=nyt /> The Director of Information Technology Council at the Iranian Ministry of Industries and Mines, Mahmud Liaii, has said that: "An [[Cyberwarfare|electronic war]] has been launched against Iran... This computer worm is designed to transfer data about production lines from our industrial plants to locations outside Iran."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article797363.ece|title=Under cyber-attack, says Iran|publisher=The Hindu | location=Chennai, India|first=Atul|last=Aneja|date=26 September 2010}}</ref>
In response to the infection, Iran assembled a team to combat it. With more than 30,000 IP addresses affected in Iran, an official said that the infection was fast spreading in Iran and the problem had been compounded by the ability of Stuxnet to mutate. Iran had set up its own systems to clean up infections and had advised against using the Siemens SCADA antivirus since it is suspected that the antivirus was actually embedded with codes which update Stuxnet instead of eradicating it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinn.ir/Default.aspx?TabId=56&nid=193428|title=شبکه خبر :: راه های مقابله با ویروس"استاکس نت"|publisher=Irinn.ir|language=Iranian|accessdate=28 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621130831/http://www.irinn.ir/Default.aspx?TabId=56&nid=193428|archivedate=21 June 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=afp>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jnTuOwD-HMJB9A8JQUC_-E_o2IYw|title=Stuxnet worm rampaging through Iran: IT official|publisher=AFP|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5t5UjHLGB?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jnTuOwD-HMJB9A8JQUC_-E_o2IYw|archivedate=28 September 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2010/09/israel-questions-about-the-stuxnet-attack-on-iranian-computers.html|title=IRAN: Speculation on Israeli involvement in malware computer attack|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=27 September 2010|accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=post>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/27/AR2010092706229.html|title=Iran struggling to contain 'foreign-made' 'Stuxnet' computer virus|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=27 September 2010|accessdate=28 September 2010|first1=Thomas|last1=Erdbrink|first2=Ellen|last2=Nakashima}}</ref>
According to Hamid Alipour, deputy head of Iran's government Information Technology Company, "The attack is still ongoing and new versions of this virus are spreading." He reported that his company had begun the cleanup process at Iran's "sensitive centres and organizations."<ref name=afp /> "We had anticipated that we could root out the virus within one to two months, but the virus is not stable, and since we started the cleanup process three new versions of it have been spreading", he told the [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] on 27 September 2010.<ref name=post />
On 29 November 2010, Iranian president [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] stated for the first time that a computer virus had caused problems with the controller handling the centrifuges at its Natanz facilities. According to Reuters, he told reporters at a news conference in Tehran, "They succeeded in creating problems for a limited number of our centrifuges with the software they had installed in electronic parts."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/gadgets/0,1518,731881,00.html|title=Ahmadinedschad räumt Virus-Attack ein|publisher=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=29 November 2010|accessdate=29 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2010/1130/Stuxnet-Ahmadinejad-admits-cyberweapon-hit-Iran-nuclear-program|title=Stuxnet: Ahmadinejad admits cyberweapon hit Iran nuclear program|publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=30 November 2010|accessdate=29 December 2010}}</ref>
On the same day two Iranian nuclear scientists were targeted in separate, but nearly simultaneous car bomb attacks near [[Shahid Beheshti University]] in Tehran. [[Majid Shahriari]], a quantum physicist was killed. [[Fereydoon Abbasi]], a high-ranking official at the [[Ministry of Defense and Armed Forces Logistics (Iran)|Ministry of Defense]] was seriously wounded. ''Wired'' speculated that the assassinations could indicate that whoever was behind Stuxnet felt that it was not sufficient to stop the nuclear program.<ref name="wired1" /> That same ''Wired'' article suggested the [[Iranian government]] could have been behind the assassinations.<ref name="wired1" /> In January 2010, another Iranian nuclear scientist, a physics professor at [[Tehran University]], was killed in a similar bomb explosion.<ref name="wired1">{{cite news|last=Zetter |first=Kim |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/11/stuxnet-sabotage-centrifuges/ |title=Iran: Computer Malware Sabotaged Uranium Centrifuges | Threat Level |publisher=Wired.com |date=29 November 2010 |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> On 11 January 2012, a Director of the Natanz nuclear enrichment facility, [[Mostafa Ahmadi Roshan]], was killed in an attack quite similar to the one that killed Shahriari.<ref name="Fox News">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/01/11/report-bomb-kills-iran-university-professor/?test=latestnews |title=US Denies Role In Iranian Scientist's Death |publisher=Fox News |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref>
An analysis by the FAS demonstrates that Iran’s enrichment capacity grew during 2010. The study indicated that Iran’s centrifuges appeared to be performing 60% better than in the previous year, which would significantly reduce Tehran’s time to produce bomb-grade uranium. The FAS report was reviewed by an official with the IAEA who affirmed the study.<ref name=FAS>{{cite web|author= Monica Amarelo |url=https://fas.org/press/news/2011/issuebrief_iran.html|title=New FAS Report Demonstrates Iran Improved Enrichment in 2010 |publisher=[[Federation of American Scientists]] |date=21 January 2011}}</ref><ref name= Haaretz>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/report-iran-s-nuclear-capacity-unharmed-contrary-to-u-s-assessment-1.338522 |title= Report: Iran's nuclear capacity unharmed, contrary to U.S. assessment |publisher=[[Haaretz]] |date=22 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= Jeffrey Goldberg| url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/01/report-irans-nuclear-program-going-full-speed-ahead/70031/ |title= Report: Report: Iran's Nuclear Program Going Full Speed Ahead |publisher=[[The Atlantic]] |date=22 January 2011}}</ref>
European and US officials, along with private experts told Reuters that Iranian engineers were successful in neutralizing and purging Stuxnet from their country's nuclear machinery.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/14/us-iran-usa-stuxnet-idUSTRE81D24Q20120214|title=Experts say Iran has "neutralized" Stuxnet virus|publisher=Reuters |date= 14 February 2012}}</ref>
Given the growth in Iranian enrichment capability in 2010, the country may have intentionally put out [[misinformation]] to cause Stuxnet's creators to believe that the worm was more successful in disabling the Iranian nuclear program than it actually was.{{r|gross201104}}
==== Israel ==== [[Israel]], through [[Unit 8200]],<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2010/sep/30/stuxnet-worm-new-era-global-cyberwar | title=Stuxnet worm heralds new era of global cyberwar | publisher=Guardian.co.uk | date=30 September 2010 | location=London | first=Peter | last=Beaumont }}</ref><ref name="sanger">{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/01/world/middleeast/obama-ordered-wave-of-cyberattacks-against-iran.html?_r=2&pagewanted=2&seid=auto&smid=tw-nytimespolitics&pagewanted=all |title = Obama Order Sped Up Wave of Cyberattacks Against Iran |publisher = The New York Times |date = 1 June 2012 |accessdate =1 June 2012 |first = David E. |last = Sanger}}</ref> has been speculated to be the country behind Stuxnet in many media reports<ref name=guardian /><ref name=economist>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/babbage/2010/09/stuxnet_worm |title=The Stuxnet worm: A cyber-missile aimed at Iran? |publisher=The Economist |date=24 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=FP>{{cite web|last=Hounshell|first= Blake|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2010/09/27/6_mysteries_about_stuxnet|title=6 mysteries about Stuxnet|publisher=Foreign Policy|date=27 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> and by experts such as [[Richard A. Falkenrath]], former Senior Director for Policy and Plans within the US [[Office of Homeland Security]].<ref name=Yahoo!>{{cite news |title = Falkenrath Says Stuxnet Virus May Have Origin in Israel: Video. Bloomberg Television |date = 24 September 2010 |url = https://finance.yahoo.com/video/marketnews-19148628/falkenrath-says-stuxnet-virus-may-have-origin-in-israel-video-22090127#video=22147179 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121204121558/http://finance.yahoo.com/video/marketnews-19148628/falkenrath-says-stuxnet-virus-may-have-origin-in-israel-video-22090127#video=22147179 |archivedate = 4 December 2012 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>{{r|nyt}} Yossi Melman, who covers intelligence for the Israeli daily newspaper ''Haaretz'' and is writing a book about Israeli intelligence, also suspected that Israel was involved, noting that [[Meir Dagan]], the former (up until 2011) head of the national intelligence agency [[Mossad]], had his term extended in 2009 because he was said to be involved in important projects. Additionally, Israel now expects that Iran will have a nuclear weapon in 2014 or 2015 – at least three years later than earlier estimates – without the need for an Israeli military attack on Iranian nuclear facilities; "They seem to know something, that they have more time than originally thought", he added.<ref name="NYTimes20100929" />{{r|broad20110115}} Israel has not publicly commented on the Stuxnet attack but confirmed that cyberwarfare is now among the pillars of its defense doctrine, with a military intelligence unit set up to pursue both defensive and offensive options.<ref>{{cite news|last=Williams |first=Dan |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5BE30920091215 |title=Spymaster sees Israel as world cyberwar leader |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=29 May 2012 |date=15 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Dan Williams|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE68R0GB.htm|title=Cyber takes centre stage in Israel's war strategy|publisher=Reuters, 28 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Antonin Gregoire|url=http://www.iloubnan.info/politics/actualite/id/52568/titre/Stuxnet,-the-real-face-of-Cyber-Warfare|title=Stuxnet, the real face of cyber warfare|publisher=Iloubnan.info, 25 November 2010}}</ref> When questioned whether Israel was behind the virus in the fall of 2010, some Israeli officials{{who|date=July 2017}} broke into "wide smiles", fueling speculation that the government of Israel was involved with its genesis.<ref name="nyt-19stuxnet">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/19/world/middleeast/19stuxnet.html | work=The New York Times | first1=William J. | last1=Broad | first2=David E. | last2=Sanger | title=Worm in Iran Can Wreck Nuclear Centrifuges | date=18 November 2010}}</ref> American presidential advisor Gary Samore also smiled when Stuxnet was mentioned,{{r|broad20110115}} although American officials have indicated that the virus originated abroad.<ref name="nyt-19stuxnet" /> According to ''The Telegraph'', Israeli newspaper ''Haaretz'' reported that a video celebrating operational successes of [[Gabi Ashkenazi]], retiring [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] Chief of Staff, was shown at his retirement party and included references to Stuxnet, thus strengthening claims that Israel's security forces were responsible.<ref name="WilliamsCTelegraph">{{cite news | last = Williams | first = Christoper | title = Israeli security chief celebrates Stuxnet cyber attack | newspaper = The Telegraph | location = London | date = 16 February 2011 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/8326274/Israeli-security-chief-celebrates-Stuxnet-cyber-attack.html | accessdate =23 February 2011}}</ref>
In 2009, a year before Stuxnet was discovered, Scott Borg of the [[United States Cyber-Consequences Unit]] (US-CCU)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usccu.us/|title=The U.S. Cyber Consequences Unit|author=U.S. Cyber Consequences Unit|work=usccu.us}}</ref> suggested that Israel might prefer to mount a cyber-attack rather than a military strike on Iran's nuclear facilities.<ref name=EyesCyberwar /> And, in late 2010 Borg stated, "Israel certainly has the ability to create Stuxnet and there is little downside to such an attack because it would be virtually impossible to prove who did it. So a tool like Stuxnet is Israel's obvious weapon of choice."<ref name=economist2>{{cite news|title=A worm in the centrifuge: An unusually sophisticated cyber-weapon is mysterious but important|publisher=[[The Economist]]|date=30 September 2010|url=http://www.economist.com/node/17147818}}</ref> Iran uses [[P-1 centrifuge]]s at Natanz, the design for which [[A. Q. Khan]] stole in 1976 and took to Pakistan. His [[black market]] [[Nuclear proliferation#Pakistan|nuclear-proliferation network]] sold P-1s to, among other customers, Iran. Experts believe that Israel also somehow acquired P-1s and tested Stuxnet on the centrifuges, installed at the [[Negev Nuclear Research Center|Dimona]] facility that is part of [[Israel and nuclear weapons|its own nuclear program]].{{r|broad20110115}} The equipment may be from the United States, which received P-1s from [[Libya and nuclear technology|Libya's former nuclear program]].<ref>{{cite news|author= David Sanger|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/26/world/middleeast/26iran.html?_r=2&src=me|title=Iran Fights Malware Attacking Computers|publisher=New York Times|date=25 September 2010 | accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref>{{r|broad20110115}}
Some have also referred to several clues in the code such as a concealed reference to the word "MYRTUS", believed to refer to the [[Myrtaceae|Myrtle]] tree, or Hadassah in Hebrew. Hadassah was the birth name of the former Jewish queen of Persia, Queen [[Esther]].<ref name=MES>{{cite web |title= Iran/Critical National Infrastructure: Cyber Security Experts See The Hand Of Israel's Signals Intelligence Service In The "Stuxnet" Virus Which Has Infected Iranian Nuclear Facilities |date= 1 September 2010 |url= http://www.mideastsecurity.co.uk/?tag=stuxnet-myrtus-myrtle |publisher= Mideastsecurity.co.uk |access-date= 6 October 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101208204541/http://www.mideastsecurity.co.uk/?tag=stuxnet-myrtus-myrtle# |archive-date= 8 December 2010 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Riddle|first= Warren|url=http://www.switched.com/2010/10/01/mysterious-myrtus-biblical-reference-spotted-in-stuxnet-code/|title=Mysterious 'Myrtus' Biblical Reference Spotted in Stuxnet Code |publisher=SWITCHED|date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=6 October 2010}}</ref> However, it may be that the "MYRTUS" reference is simply a misinterpreted reference to [[SCADA]] components known as ''RTUs'' (Remote Terminal Units) and that this reference is actually "My RTUs"–a management feature of SCADA.<ref name=scada_rtus>{{cite web|url=https://www.motorola.com/web/Business/Products/SCADA%20Products/_Documents/Static%20Files/SCADA_Sys_Wht_Ppr-2a_New.pdf|title=SCADA Systems Whitepaper|publisher=Motorola}}</ref> Also, the number 19790509 appears once in the code and might refer to the date "1979 May 09", the day [[Habib Elghanian]], a Persian Jew, was executed in [[Tehran]].<ref name="symantec_dossier">{{cite web|url=http://www.symantec.com/content/en/us/enterprise/media/security_response/whitepapers/w32_stuxnet_dossier.pdf|title=W32.Stuxnet Dossier|publisher=Symantec Corporation}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2370107,00.asp|title=Symantec Puts 'Stuxnet' Malware Under the Knife|publisher=PC Magazine}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/10/stuxnet-deconstructed/|title=New Clues Point to Israel as Author of Blockbuster Worm, Or Not|publisher=Wired | first=Kim|last=Zetter|date=1 October 2010}}</ref> Another date that appears in the code is "24 September 2007", the day that Iran's president [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] spoke at [[Columbia University]] and made comments questioning the validity of the [[Holocaust]].{{r|gross201104}} Such data is not conclusive, since, as noted by Symantec, "...attackers would have the natural desire to implicate another party".<ref name="symantec_dossier" />
==== United States ==== There has also been testimony on the involvement of the United States and its collaboration with Israel,<ref name="us">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-501465_162-20017507-501465.html| title=Stuxnet Worm a U.S. Cyber-Attack on Iran Nukes?|publisher=CBS News | first=Tucker|last=Reals|date=24 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Snowden Der Spiegel Interview|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/interview-with-whistleblower-edward-snowden-on-global-spying-a-910006.html|publisher=Der Spiegel|accessdate=3 October 2015|language=English, German}}</ref> with one report stating that "there is vanishingly little doubt that [it] played a role in creating the worm."{{r|gross201104}} It has been reported that the United States, under one of its most secret programs, initiated by the Bush administration and accelerated{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} by the Obama administration,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/obama--us-israeli-against-iran-2012-6#ixzz1wYnaa3jK|title=Obama Administration Admits Cyberattacks Against Iran Are Part Of Joint US-Israeli Offensive|last=Kelley|first=Michael B.|date=1 June 2012|website=Business Insider|accessdate=23 January 2018}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> has sought to destroy Iran's nuclear program by novel methods such as undermining Iranian computer systems. A [[United States diplomatic cables leak|diplomatic cable]] obtained by [[WikiLeaks]] showed how the United States was advised to target Iran's nuclear capabilities through 'covert sabotage'.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/18/wikileaks-us-embassy-cable-iran-nuclear |title=WikiLeaks: the US advised to sabotage Iran nuclear sites by German thinktank |author=Halliday, Josh |work=The Guardian |date=18 January 2011 |accessdate=19 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> A New York Times article as early as January 2009 credited a then unspecified program with preventing an Israeli military attack on Iran where some of the efforts focused on ways to destabilize the centrifuges.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/11/washington/11iran.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | title=U.S. Rejected Aid for Israeli Raid on Iranian Nuclear Site | date=10 January 2009 | author=David E. Sanger | publisher=The New York Times | accessdate=12 October 2013 }}</ref> A ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' article claimed that Stuxnet "is believed to have been created by the United States".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/02/cyberwar-issues-likely-to-be-addressed-only-after-a-catastrophe | title=Cyberwar Issues Likely to Be Addressed Only After a Catastrophe | date=17 February 2011 | author=Kim Zetter | publisher=Wired | accessdate=18 February 2011 }}</ref>
The fact that John Bumgarner, a former intelligence officer and member of the United States Cyber-Consequences Unit (US-CCU), published an article prior to Stuxnet being discovered or deciphered, that outlined a strategic cyber strike on centrifuges<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.stripes.com/news/cone-of-silence-surrounds-u-s-cyberwarfare-1.158090 | title=Cone of silence surrounds U.S. cyberwarfare | date=18 October 2011 | author=Chris Carroll | publisher=Stars and Stripes | accessdate=30 October 2011 }}</ref> and suggests that cyber attacks are permissible against nation states which are operating uranium enrichment programs that violate international treaties gives some credibility to these claims. Bumgarner pointed out that the centrifuges used to process fuel for nuclear weapons are a key target for ''cybertage'' operations and that they can be made to destroy themselves by manipulating their rotational speeds.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.crows.org/images/stories/pdf/IOI/IO%20Journal_Vol2Iss2_0210.pdf |title = Computers as Weapons of War |date = 27 April 2010 |author = John Bumgarner |publisher = IO Journal |accessdate = 30 October 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111219174833/http://www.crows.org/images/stories/pdf/IOI/IO%20Journal_Vol2Iss2_0210.pdf |archivedate = 19 December 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In a March 2012 interview with ''[[60 Minutes]]'', retired [[US Air Force]] General [[Michael Hayden (general)|Michael Hayden]] – who served as director of both the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] and [[National Security Agency]] – while denying knowledge of who created Stuxnet said that he believed it had been "a good idea" but that it carried a downside in that it had legitimized the use of sophisticated cyber weapons designed to cause physical damage. Hayden said, "There are those out there who can take a look at this... and maybe even attempt to turn it to their own purposes". In the same report, Sean McGurk, a former cybersecurity official at the [[Department of Homeland Security]] noted that the Stuxnet source code could now be downloaded online and modified to be directed at new target systems. Speaking of the Stuxnet creators, he said, "They opened the box. They demonstrated the capability... It's not something that can be put back."<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18560_162-57390124/stuxnet-computer-worm-opens-new-era-of-warfare/ |title = Stuxnet: Computer worm opens new era of warfare |publisher = [[60 Minutes]] (CBS News) |date = 4 March 2012 |accessdate =9 March 2012 |first = Steve |last = Kroft }}</ref>
==== Joint effort and other states and targets ==== {{update section|date=June 2012}}<!--in light of the NYT comment in the LEAD this is outdated as moot/speculation--> In April 2011 Iranian government official Gholam Reza Jalali stated that an investigation had concluded that the United States and Israel were behind the Stuxnet attack.<ref>{{cite news | author= CBS News staff | authorlink = CBS News | title = Iran blames U.S., Israel for Stuxnet malware | work = | publisher = CBS News | date = 16 April 2011 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/04/16/501364/main20054574.shtml | format = SHTML | doi = | accessdate = 15 January 2012 }}</ref> Frank Rieger stated that three European countries' intelligence agencies agreed that Stuxnet was a joint United States-Israel effort. The code for the Windows injector and the PLC payload differ in style, likely implying collaboration. Other experts believe that a US-Israel cooperation is unlikely because "the level of trust between the two countries’ intelligence and military establishments is not high."{{r|gross201104}}
A Wired magazine article about US General [[Keith B. Alexander]] stated: "And he and his cyber warriors have already launched their first attack. The cyber weapon that came to be known as Stuxnet was created and built by the NSA in partnership with the CIA and Israeli intelligence in the mid-2000s."<ref>{{cite news | author= James Balford | title = THE SECRET WAR | work = | publisher = Wired | date = 12 June 2013 | url = https://www.wired.com/2013/06/general-keith-alexander-cyberwar/all/ | doi = | accessdate = 2 June 2014 }}</ref>
[[China]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/firewall/2010/12/14/stuxnets-finnish-chinese-connection/|title=Stuxnet's Finnish-Chinese Connection|publisher=[[Forbes]]|date=14 December 2010 | accessdate=19 April 2011|last=Carr|first=Jeffrey}}</ref> [[Jordan]], and [[France]] are other possibilities, and Siemens may have also participated.{{r|gross201104}}{{r|us}} Langner speculated that the infection may have spread from USB drives belonging to Russian contractors since the Iranian targets were not accessible via the Internet.<ref name=RewritingPlaybook /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2010/0924/Stuxnet-worm-mystery-What-s-the-cyber-weapon-after|title=Stuxnet worm mystery: What's the cyber weapon after?|publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=24 September 2010 | accessdate=21 January 2011|last=Clayton|first=Mark}}</ref>
Sandro Gaycken from the [[Free University Berlin]] argued that the attack on Iran was a ruse to distract from Stuxnet's real purpose. According to him, its broad dissemination in more than 100,000 industrial plants worldwide suggests a field test of a cyber weapon in different security cultures, testing their preparedness, resilience, and reactions, all highly valuable information for a cyberwar unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/2010/48/Computerwurm-Stuxnet|title=Stuxnet: Wer war's? Und wozu?|publisher=[[Die ZEIT]]|date=26 November 2010 | accessdate=19 April 2011|last=Gaycken|first=Sandro}}</ref>
The [[United Kingdom]] has denied involvement in the worm's creation.<ref name="grauniad">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/may/30/military-cyberwar-offensive|title=UK developing cyber-weapons programme to counter cyber war threat|last=Hopkins|first=Nick|date=31 May 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=31 May 2011|location=[[United Kingdom]]}}</ref>
[[Stratfor]] Documents released by Wikileaks suggest that the International Security Firm 'Stratfor' believe that Israel is behind Stuxnet – "But we can't assume that because they did Stuxnet that they are capable of doing this blast as well".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/185945_re-alpha-s3-g3-israel-iran-barak-hails-munitions-blast-in.html |title=The Global Intelligence Files – Re: [alpha] S3/G3* ISRAEL/IRAN – Barak hails munitions blast in Iran |publisher=Wikileaks |date=14 November 2011 |accessdate=4 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120727115704/http://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/185945_re-alpha-s3-g3-israel-iran-barak-hails-munitions-blast-in.html |archivedate=27 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In July 2013, [[Edward Snowden]] claimed that Stuxnet was cooperatively developed by the United States and [[Israel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/07/08/snowden_us_israel_stuxnet/|title=Snowden: US and Israel Did Create Stuxnet Attack Code|author=Iain Thomson|publisher=The Register|date=8 July 2013|accessdate=8 July 2013}}</ref>
=== Deployment in North Korea === According to a report by Reuters, the NSA also tried to sabotage [[North Korea]]'s [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear program]] using a version of Stuxnet. The operation was reportedly launched in tandem with the attack that targeted Iranian centrifuges in 2009–10. The North Korean nuclear program shares many similarities with the Iranian, both having been developed with technology transferred by Pakistani nuclear scientist [[A.Q. Khan]]. The effort failed, however, because North Korea's extreme secrecy and isolation made it impossible to introduce Stuxnet into the nuclear facility.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Menn|first1=Joseph|title=Exclusive: U.S. tried Stuxnet-style campaign against North Korea but failed – sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/29/us-usa-northkorea-stuxnet-idUSKBN0OE2DM20150529|accessdate=31 May 2015|agency=Reuters|date=29 May 2015}}</ref>
== Related malware ==
=== "Stuxnet's Secret Twin" === A November 2013 article<ref>{{cite web | url = https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2013/11/19/stuxnets_secret_twin_iran_nukes_cyber_attack | title = Stuxnet's Secret Twin | publisher = Foreign Policy | date = 19 November 2013}}</ref> in Foreign Policy magazine claims existence of an earlier, much more sophisticated attack on the centrifuge complex at Natanz, focused on increasing centrifuge failure rate over a long time period by stealthily inducing uranium hexafluoride gas overpressure incidents. This malware was capable of spreading only by being physically installed, probably by previously contaminated field equipment used by contractors working on Siemens control systems within the complex. It is not clear whether this attack attempt was successful, but it being followed by a different, simpler and more conventional attack is indicative.
=== Duqu === {{Main|Duqu}} On 1 September 2011, a new worm was found, thought to be related to Stuxnet. The Laboratory of Cryptography and System Security (CrySyS) of the [[Budapest University of Technology and Economics]] analyzed the malware, naming the threat '''Duqu'''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.crysys.hu/publications/files/bencsathPBF11duqu.pdf | title = Duqu: A Stuxnet-like malware found in the wild, technical report | publisher = Laboratory of Cryptography of Systems Security (CrySyS) | date = 14 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crysys.hu/in-the-press.html |title=Statement on Duqu's initial analysis |publisher=Laboratory of Cryptography of Systems Security (CrySyS) |date=21 October 2011 |accessdate=25 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6B98SI8gJ?url=http://www.crysys.hu/in-the-press.html |archivedate=3 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Symantec]], based on this report, continued the analysis of the threat, calling it "nearly identical to Stuxnet, but with a completely different purpose", and published a detailed technical paper.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.symantec.com/content/en/us/enterprise/media/security_response/whitepapers/w32_duqu_the_precursor_to_the_next_stuxnet.pdf |title=W32.Duqu – The precursor to the next Stuxnet (Version 1.2) |work= |publisher=[[Symantec]] |date=20 October 2011 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> The main component used in Duqu is designed to capture information<ref name=SonsOfStuxnet /> such as keystrokes and system information. The exfiltrated data may be used to enable a future Stuxnet-like attack. On 28 December 2011, Kaspersky Lab's director of global research and analysis spoke to Reuters about recent research results showing that the platform Stuxnet and Duqu both originated from in 2007, and is being referred to as Tilded due to the ~d at the beginning of the file names. Also uncovered in this research was the possibility for three more variants based on the Tilded platform.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jim Finkle|title=Stuxnet weapon has at least 4 cousins: researchers|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/28/us-cybersecurity-stuxnet-idUSTRE7BR1EV20111228|publisher=Reuters|date=28 December 2011}}</ref>
=== Flame === {{Main|Flame (malware)}} In May 2012, the new malware "Flame" was found, thought to be related to Stuxnet.<ref name=Zetter>{{cite news |title=Meet 'Flame,' The Massive Spy Malware Infiltrating Iranian Computers |first=Kim |last=Zetter |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/05/flame/ |newspaper=Wired |date=28 May 2012 |accessdate=29 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6834BiIOh?url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/05/flame/ |archivedate=30 May 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Researchers named the program "Flame" after the name of one of its modules.<ref name=Zetter /> After analysing the code of Flame, Kaspersky Lab said that there is a strong relationship between Flame and Stuxnet. An early version of Stuxnet contained code to propagate infections via USB drives that is nearly identical to a Flame module that exploits the same vulnerability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kaspersky.com/about/news/virus/2012/Resource_207_Kaspersky_Lab_Research_Proves_that_Stuxnet_and_Flame_Developers_are_Connected|title=Resource 207: Kaspersky Lab Research Proves that Stuxnet and Flame Developers are Connected|date=11 June 2012|publisher=Kaspersky Lab}}</ref>
=== Triton === In December 2017 it was reported that the safety systems of an unidentified power station, believed to be in [[Saudi Arabia]], were compromised, when the [[Triconex]] industrial safety technology made by Schneider Electric SE was targeted, in what is believed to have been a state sponsored attack. The computer security company [[Symantec]] claimed that the malware, known as "Triton", exploited a vulnerability in computers running the [[Microsoft Windows]] operating system.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/dec/15/triton-hackers-malware-attack-safety-systems-energy-plant|title=Triton: hackers take out safety systems in 'watershed' attack on energy plant|last=Gibbs|first=Samuel|date=15 December 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=16 December 2017|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
== Media coverage == Since 2010, there has been extensive international media coverage on Stuxnet and its aftermath. In early commentary, ''[[The Economist]]'' pointed out that Stuxnet was "a new kind of cyber-attack."<ref>{{cite news|title=The Meaning of Stuxnet|url=http://www.economist.com/node/17147862|publisher=The Economist|date=30 September 2010}}</ref> On 8 July 2011, ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' then published an article detailing how network security experts were able to decipher the origins of Stuxnet. In that piece, Kim Zetter claimed that Stuxnet's "cost–benefit ratio is still in question."<ref>{{cite news|author=Kim Zetter|title=How Digital Detectives Deciphered Stuxnet, the Most Menacing Malware in History|url=https://www.wired.com/2011/07/how-digital-detectives-deciphered-stuxnet/|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=8 July 2011}}</ref> Later commentators tended to focus on the strategic significance of Stuxnet as a cyber weapon. Following the Wired piece, Holger Stark called Stuxnet the "first digital weapon of geopolitical importance, it could change the way wars are fought."<ref>{{cite news|author=Holger Stark|title=Mossad's Miracle Weapon: Stuxnet Virus Opens New Era of Cyber War|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/mossad-s-miracle-weapon-stuxnet-virus-opens-new-era-of-cyber-war-a-778912.html|work=Der Spiegel|date=8 August 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile, Eddie Walsh referred to Stuxnet as "the world's newest high-end asymmetric threat."<ref>{{cite news|author=Eddie Walsh|title=2011: The year of domestic cyber threat|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2012/01/20121181245291117.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=1 January 2012}}</ref> Ultimately, some claim that the "extensive media coverage afforded to Stuxnet has only served as an advertisement for the vulnerabilities used by various cybercriminal groups."<ref>{{cite news|author=Vyacheslav Zakorzhevsky|title=Sality & Stuxnet – Not Such a Strange Coincidence|url=http://www.kaspersky.com/about/news/virus/2010/Sality_Stuxnet_Not_Such_a_Strange_Coincidence|publisher=Kaspersky Lab|date=5 October 2010}}</ref> While that may be the case, the media coverage has also increased awareness of cyber security threats.
[[Alex Gibney]]'s 2016 documentary ''[[Zero Days]]'' covers the phenomenon around Stuxnet.<ref>{{cite web |date=16 February 2016 |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamesball/us-hacked-into-irans-critical-civilian-infrastructure-for-ma |title=U.S. Hacked Into Iran's Critical Civilian Infrastructure For Massive Cyberattack, New Film Claims |work=[[BuzzFeed]] |first=James |last=Ball}}</ref>
In 2016 it was revealed that [[James Cartwright|General James Cartwright]], the former head of the U.S. Strategic Command, had leaked information related to Stuxnet. He later pleaded guilty for lying to FBI agents pursuing an investigation into the leak.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/18/us/marine-general-james-cartwright-leak-fbi.html|title=James Cartwright, Ex-General, Pleads Guilty in Leak Case|last=Savage|first=Charlie|date=17 October 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/world-war-three-by-mistake|title=World War Three, by Mistake|date=23 December 2016|website=The New Yorker|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref> On 17 January 2017, he was granted a full pardon in this case by President Obama, thereby expunging his conviction.
== In popular culture == * In ''[[Castle (TV series)|Castle]]'' [[List of Castle episodes#Season 8 (2015–16)|season 8, episode 18 "Backstabber"]] Stuxnet is revealed to have been (fictionally) created by [[MI-6]], and a version of it is used to take down the London power grid. * ''Trojan Horse'' is a novel written by Windows utility writer, and novelist Mark Russinovich. It features the usage of the Stuxnet virus as a main plot line for the story, and the attempt of Iran to bypass it. * In ''[[Ghost in the Shell: Arise]]'' Stuxnet is the name of the computer virus which infected [[Motoko Kusanagi|Kusanagi]] and Manamura allowing false memories to be implanted. * In July 2017, MRSA ([[Mat Zo]]) released a track named "Stuxnet" through [[Hospital Records]]. * In Ubisoft's 2013 video game ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist]]'', the protagonist, Sam Fisher, makes use of a mobile, airborne headquarters ("Paladin") which is said at one point within the game's story mode to have been targeted by a Stuxnet-style virus, causing its systems to fail and the plane to careen towards the ocean, and would have crashed without Fisher's intervening.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o77cNhuoI4A</ref>

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox waka |waka_name = ''Te Paepae-ki-Rarotonga'' |commander = |priest = |departed = |landed = |iwi = }} In [[Māori mythology|Māori tradition]], '''''Te Paepae-ki-Rarotonga''''' was one of the great [[Māori migration canoes|ocean-going, voyaging canoes]] that was used in the migrations that settled [[New Zealand]]. ''Te Paepae-ki-Rarotonga'' was captained by Waitaha-ariki-kore and is said to have landed near [[Matatā]].<ref>http://www.teara.govt.nz/NewZealanders/MaoriNewZealanders/CanoeTraditions/4/en Te Ara: Encyclopedia of New Zealand</ref>
==Traditions==
Waitaha-Ariki-Kore pulled down his house in Rarotonga and used it to build his waka ''Te Paepae-o-Rarotonga''.
He was guided to Aotearoa by two taniwha and made first landfall at the Rurima Islands. He approached the islands at speed and on striking them caused them to break apart. At Rurima he sought water at the spring which bears his name.
From Rurima he then crossed to the mainland landing at Te Awa o te Atua, near Matata, before proceeding past Otaramuturangi to Te Kohika. From here he travelled to the inland of the Bay of Plenty.
Ngatiawa expressly state that ''Te Paepae-o-Rarotonga'' arrived before the coming of ''Mātaatua'', and it is said to have been a very tapu craft; hence the place where it lay (The canoe is said to be lying, buried, at Tara-o-muturangi) was used as a burial-place.
Waiataha-ariki-kore married Hineteariki of Hapuoneone who had her pā at Otamarakau and inland to Waitahanui. Their daughter was Hahuru the mother of Tuwharetoa i te Aupouri.
According to Colonel Gudgeon, the Rarotongan natives have a tradition concerning a canoe called ''Te Paepae-o-Rarotonga''.
