'''''The Flash''''' is an American [[superhero fiction|superhero]] television series developed by [[Greg Berlanti]], [[Andrew Kreisberg]], and [[Geoff Johns]], airing on [[The CW]]. It is based on the [[DC Comics]] character [[Flash (Barry Allen)|Barry Allen / Flash]], a costumed superhero crime-fighter with the power to move at superhuman speeds. It is a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] from ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]]'', existing in the same [[Arrowverse|fictional universe]]. The series follows [[Barry Allen (Arrowverse)|Allen]], portrayed by [[Grant Gustin]], a crime scene investigator who gains super-human speed, which he uses to fight criminals, including others who have also gained superhuman abilities.
Initially envisioned as a [[backdoor pilot]], the positive reception Gustin received during two appearances as Barry on ''Arrow'' led to executives choosing to develop a full pilot to make use of a larger budget and help flesh out Barry's world in more detail. [[Colleen Atwood]], costume designer for ''Arrow'', was brought in to design the Flash's suit. The creative team wanted to make sure that the Flash would resemble his comic book counterpart, and not simply be a poor imitation. The series is primarily filmed in [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada.
''The Flash'' premiered in North America on October 7, 2014, where the pilot became the second-most watched premiere in the history of The CW, after ''[[The Vampire Diaries (TV series)|The Vampire Diaries]]'' in 2009. It has been well received by critics and audiences, and won the [[People's Choice Award]] for "Favorite New TV Drama" in 2014. The series, together with ''Arrow'', has spun characters out to their own show, ''[[Legends of Tomorrow]]'', which premiered on January 21, 2016. On April 2, 2018, The CW renewed the series for a [[The Flash (season 5)|fifth season]], which premiered on October 9, 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/riverdale-flash-supernatural-10-cw-renewals-1098997 |title='Riverdale,' 'Flash,' 'Supernatural' Among 10 CW Renewals |last=Goldberg |first=Leslie |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=April 2, 2018 |accessdate=April 2, 2018}}</ref><ref name="PremiereDate">{{Cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/the-cw-fall-2018-premiere-dates-charmed-all-american-legacies-1202414400/ |title=The CW Sets Fall Premiere Dates, Including Sunday Lineup & Three Series Debuts |last=Pedersen |first=Erik |date=June 20, 2018 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180621004604/https://deadline.com/2018/06/the-cw-fall-2018-premiere-dates-charmed-all-american-legacies-1202414400/ |archive-date=June 21, 2018 |dead-url=no |access-date=June 20, 2018}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|3}}
==Series overview== {{update|section|date=June 2018}}<!--Season 4 overview stops right before Crisis on Earth-X, while preceding seasons go as far as finale--> {{main|List of The Flash episodes}} In season one, after witnessing his mother's supernatural murder, Barry Allen is taken in by Detective Joe West and his family. Barry becomes a brilliant but socially awkward crime scene investigator for the [[Central City Police Department]]. A particle accelerator malfunctions, bathing the city center with a radiation during a thunderstorm, and Barry is struck by lightning. Awakening after a coma, he discovers he can move at superhuman speeds. Harrison Wells, the accelerator's designer, describes Barry's nature as "[[metahuman]]". Barry vows to use his gifts to protect [[Central City (DC Comics)|Central City]]. As the [[Flash (comics)|Flash]], Barry also pursues his mother's murderer, the [[Eobard Thawne|Reverse-Flash]].<ref name="S1LogLine"/>
In season two, after a [[Gravitational singularity|singularity]] event occurs, the Flash is recognized as Central City's hero. However, the event brings a new threat from a [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel earth]]: [[Hunter Zolomon#Television|Zoom]], a demonic speedster who seeks to eliminate all speedsters throughout the [[Multiverse (DC Comics)|multiverse]]. Harrison Wells' parallel universe counterpart nicknamed "Harry", and his daughter [[Jesse Quick|Jesse]], work to help Barry stop Zoom and explore the multiverse. Joe and his daughter, Iris, struggle with the arrival of Iris's brother [[Wally West]]. After Zoom kills Barry's father, and following Zoom's defeat, Barry travels back in time to save his mother's life.
In season three, by changing his past, Barry alters the timeline, resulting in the alternate timeline "Flashpoint". Though he is somewhat able to restore the timeline, this creates new threats, including the emergence of [[Savitar (comics)#Television|Savitar]], a god-like speedster with a grudge against Barry. After Harry and Jesse return to Earth-2, another Wells [[doppelgänger]] is recruited: the novelist "H.R." Wells. Both Wally and [[Caitlin Snow (Arrowverse)|Caitlin Snow]] begin to manifest metahuman abilities; Wally suits up as the speedster [[Kid Flash]], while Caitlin is forced to suppress her ice-powers to prevent Killer Frost from emerging. When Barry accidentally travels to the future and sees Iris killed by Savitar, he becomes desperate to change the future to prevent that from happening. After saving Iris and defeating Savitar, Barry takes his place in the Speed Force in order to repent for his creation of Flashpoint.
In season four, following Barry's departure, Wally and Cisco have barely been able to protect Central City. When a new foe defeats them easily, requesting a battle against the Flash, the team decides to bring Barry back. While they manage to do so, Barry's return releases dark matter, turning a dozen people on a city bus into metahumans. One of these metas is private detective [[Ralph Dibny]], who joins the Flash's team. The team later encounters [[Thinker (DC Comics)|Clifford DeVoe]], an adversary with the fastest mind alive, who has orchestrated Barry's return from the Speed Force as well as the creation of the bus metas. Harry Wells, with his parallel universe counterparts, establish an alliance coined the Council of Wells to assist Team Flash in stopping DeVoe. Following the Thinker's defeat, the team is approached by Barry and Iris' daughter from the future, [[Tornado Twins|Nora West-Allen]], who claims to have made "a big, big mistake".
In season five, Barry is approached by his daughter, Nora West-Allen, who has arrived from the future to spend time with him. However, the team quickly discovers that Nora's presence not only altered the timeline, but unleashed a new threat in the form of Cicada, a serial killer bent on killing metahumans. In addition, they discover that meta-technology was created following their battle with the Thinker, meaning anyone wielding meta-tech can utilize the power of a metahuman. The Council of Wells sends one of their doppelgängers, detective Sherloque Wells, to aid Team Flash in countering these crises.  {{:List of The Flash episodes}}
==Cast and characters== {{Main|List of The Flash characters|List of Arrowverse actors}} * [[Grant Gustin]] as [[Barry Allen (Arrowverse)|Barry Allen / The Flash]]: {{Cast list break|A [[Central City (DC Comics)|Central City]] assistant police forensic investigator. Moments after an explosion at the [[S.T.A.R. Labs]] particle accelerator, Barry is struck by lightning in his laboratory and doused by chemicals affected by the accident. When he awakens from a nine-month coma, he has superhuman speed.<ref name="Gustin" /> In September 2013, Grant Gustin was cast in the titular role.<ref name="Gustin" /> [[Andy Mientus]], who would eventually be cast as [[Pied Piper (comics)|Hartley Rathaway]], also auditioned for the role.<ref name="MientusFlashAudition" /> Gustin began researching the character during the audition process, and reading as many comics as possible. Gustin primarily focused on [[The New 52]] series of comics, because he knew it would be difficult to read everything and he felt the New 52 was the closest to the show's "look and feel".<ref name="AccessHoll">{{cite web |url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/the-flash-qanda-grant-gustin-talks-taking-on-barry-allen-his-amazing-superhero-suit_article_99383 |title=''The Flash'' Q&A: Grant Gustin Talks Taking On Barry Allen, His Amazing Superhero Suit! |first1=Jolie |last1=Lash |first2=Anthony |last2=Ramos |date=October 7, 2014 |accessdate=December 25, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223061445/http://www.accesshollywood.com/the-flash-qanda-grant-gustin-talks-taking-on-barry-allen-his-amazing-superhero-suit_article_99383 |archivedate=December 23, 2014}}</ref>}} * [[Candice Patton]] as [[Iris West]]: The daughter of Joe West, sister to Wally West, and Barry Allen's wife, getting engaged in "[[Duet (The Flash)|Duet]]" and marrying during the ''[[Crisis on Earth-X]]'' event.<ref name="Patton" /> She works at Central City Picture News as a journalist.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Iris West "The Flash" Character Description Surfaces Following "Arrow" Ratings Jump |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=49531 |website=Comic Book Resources |access-date=January 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160206144200/http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=49531 |archivedate=February 6, 2016}}</ref> * [[Danielle Panabaker]] as [[Caitlin Snow (Arrowverse)|Caitlin Snow / Killer Frost]]:<ref name="Firestorm" /> {{Cast list break|A highly intelligent bioengineering expert, Caitlin believed her fiancé, Ronnie Raymond,<ref name="Firestorm" /> was killed during the particle accelerator explosion at S.T.A.R. Labs,<ref name="Cosnett/Panabaker" /> until he returned part way through first season. Ronnie and Caitlin get married in the first season finale, "Fast Enough".<ref name="FastEnough">{{cite web |first=Jesse |last=Schedeen |title=THE FLASH: "FAST ENOUGH" REVIEW |url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2015/05/20/the-flash-fast-enough-review |website=IGN |accessdate=May 21, 2015 |date=May 19, 2015}}</ref> }} * [[Rick Cosnett]] as Eddie Thawne: A recent transfer to the Central City Police Department, Eddie's past is a mystery and he harbored a dark secret.<ref name="Cosnett/Panabaker" /> He was partner to Detective Joe West and Iris West's love interest. Cosnett left the series after the first season, following his character's sacrifice to wipe [[Eobard Thawne]], his distant descendant, from history.<ref name="FastEnough" /> * [[Carlos Valdes (actor)|Carlos Valdes]] as [[Vibe (comics)|Cisco Ramon / Vibe]]: A mechanical engineering genius, Cisco is the youngest member of the team of scientists at S.T.A.R. Labs and a metahuman.<ref name="Valdes" /> * [[Tom Cavanagh]] as [[Harrison Wells]]: {{Cast list break|The mind and money behind Central City's [[S.T.A.R. Labs]] [[Particle Accelerator]], Wells becomes a pariah after the lab explodes.<ref name="Cavanagh" /> Mentoring Barry to get faster, he is eventually revealed to be the [[Reverse-Flash]], [[Eobard Thawne]] ([[Matt Letscher]]), a descendant of Eddie from the future with a grudge against the Flash. Thawne killed the real Wells and stole his identity.<ref name="WellsThawne" /> In subsequent seasons, Cavanagh portrays various [[Parallel universe (fiction)|alternate reality]] doppelgängers of Wells. These include the sarcastic but brilliant "Harry", who along with his daughter [[Jesse Quick|Jesse]] hails from [[Earth-Two|Earth-2]], his [[Earth-19]] counterpart, the sci-fi novelist "H.R." and their counterpart, the detective Sherloque.}} * [[Jesse L. Martin]] as [[Joe West (Arrowverse)|Joe West]]: A police detective who acts as a surrogate father to Barry, after his mother's death and father's imprisonment, and who is the father of Iris<ref name="S1LogLine" /><ref name="Martin" /> and Wally.<ref name="WallyJoeSon" /> He also now has a daughter with his fiancée, district attorney Cecille Horton, named Jenna West. Martin later taking a medical leave of absence from the show during season five after suffering a back injury.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Agard |first1=Chancellor |title=Jesse L. Martin is taking a medical leave of absence from The Flash |url=https://ew.com/tv/2018/10/31/jesse-l-martin-medical-leave-of-absence-the-flash/ |website=EW.com |publisher=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref>   * [[Keiynan Lonsdale]] as [[Wally West II|Wally West / Kid Flash]]: {{Cast list break|The son of Joe and brother of Iris, born without their knowledge after his mother left Central City.<ref name="WallyJoeSon">{{cite web |first=Eric |last=Goldman |title=The Flash Producer Talks Wally West, King Shark and the Next Arrow Crossover |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/10/28/the-flash-producer-talks-wally-west-king-shark-and-the-next-arrow-crossover|website=IGN |accessdate=October 28, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030042716/http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/10/28/the-flash-producer-talks-wally-west-king-shark-and-the-next-arrow-crossover |archivedate=October 30, 2015}}</ref> The producers disliked the introduction of relatives of characters that were never previously mentioned, feeling it was "weird", and opted instead to introduce Wally as unknown even to his relatives. They also chose to make him Iris' brother, a departure from the comics where he was her nephew.<ref name="WallyJoeSon" /> Speaking on Lonsdale's casting, Kreisberg explained that "Just like when we met Grant [Gustin] for the first time, we instantly knew Keiynan embodied all the heart and courage of a hero."<ref name=WallyFlashS2>{{cite news|first=Eric|last=Goldman|title=THE FLASH: WALLY WEST CAST FOR SEASON 2|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/08/05/the-flash-wally-west-cast-for-season-2 |accessdate=August 5, 2015 |publisher=IGN|date=August 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150805215933/http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/08/05/the-flash-wally-west-cast-for-season-2|archivedate=August 5, 2015}}</ref> After Flashpoint, Wally eventually gets speed powers from [[Doctor Alchemy]] and becomes Kid Flash. In season four, he leaves Central City to break out of Barry's shadow, and during that time joins the Legends. He returns home following the birth of half-sister Jenna West.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2016/07/12/wally-west-kid-flash-photo-the-flash-season-3-spoilers/|title=The Flash First Look: Meet Kid Flash|website=TVLine|first=Vlada|last=Gelman|date=July 12, 2016|accessdate=July 12, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713155453/https://tvline.com/2016/07/12/wally-west-kid-flash-photo-the-flash-season-3-spoilers/|archivedate=July 13, 2016}}</ref>}} * [[Neil Sandilands]] as [[Thinker (DC Comics)|Clifford DeVoe / The Thinker]]: A college professor and metahuman with a genius-level intellect, who looks to fix all that he deems wrong with humanity.<ref name="SDCC2017Panel">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/07/22/flash-comic-con-season-4-spoilers/|title=The Flash casts The 100 alum as The Thinker, adds Danny Trejo|last=Abrams|first=Natalie|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=July 22, 2017|accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref> * [[Hartley Sawyer]] as [[Elongated Man|Ralph Dibny / Elongated Man]]: A private investigator, former corrupt CCPD cop, and metahuman with superpowers including body elasticity and malleablility who becomes a member of Team Flash.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/the-flash-season-5-hartley-sawyer-elongated-man-series-regular-the-cw-1202411128/|title='The Flash': Hartley Sawyer Upped To Series Regular On The CW Superhero Drama|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Erik|last=Pedersen|date=June 15, 2018}}</ref> * [[Danielle Nicolet]] as Cecile Horton: A district attorney who becomes Joe West's girlfriend and the mother of their daughter Jenna West. While pregnant, she experiences temporary [[telepathy|telepathic]] metahuman superpowers.<ref name="Nicolet">{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/the-flash-danielle-nicolet-promoted-series-regular-1202409871/|title='The Flash': Danielle Nicolet Upped To Series Regular For Season 5 Of CW Drama |website=Deadline Hollywood |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |date=June 13, 2018}}</ref> * [[Jessica Parker Kennedy]] as Nora West-Allen / [[XS (comics)|XS]]: Barry and Iris' speedster daughter from the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tvline.com/2018/06/18/flash-season-5-jessica-parker-kennedy-series-regular-daughter-nora/|title=The Flash: Jessica Parker Kennedy Will Be a Series Regular for Season 5|website=TVLine|first=Matt Webb|last=Mitovich|date=June 18, 2018}}</ref> * [[Chris Klein (actor)|Chris Klein]] as [[Cicada (comics)|Orlin Dwyer / Cicada]]: A meta-human serial killer, who is determined to wipe out all meta-humans.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Flash season 5 casts American Pie's Chris Klein as the next big bad|url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/07/21/the-flash-season-5-chris-klein-cicada/|work=Entertainment Weekly|author=Romano, Nick|date=July 21, 2018|accessdate=July 21, 2018}}</ref>
==Production==
===Development=== On July 30, 2013, it was announced that ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]]'' co-creators [[Greg Berlanti]] and [[Andrew Kreisberg]], ''Arrow'' pilot director [[David Nutter]], and DC Comics CCO [[Geoff Johns]] would develop a television series based on the Flash for [[The CW]], and it would detail Barry Allen's origin.<ref name="DeadlineAnnouncement"/> Kreisberg revealed after the announcement that Allen would first appear as a recurring character on ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]]'' in three episodes of season two—all written by Berlanti, Kreisberg and Johns—and the last of the episodes would act as a [[backdoor pilot]] for the new show. Kreisberg added that Allen would be a forensic scientist and the introduction of his superpowers, as well as the reactions to this, will be very human and grounded. Johns stated that the character of the Flash in the show would resemble his comic book counterpart, complete with his trademark red costume, and not be a poor imitation. Kreisberg elaborated: "No sweat suits or strange code names; he ''will be'' The Flash." While researching the best way to depict the Flash's lightning speed, Johns stated it would not just be the standard "blurring around".<ref name="THRJuly2013"/>
Barry ultimately appeared twice in ''Arrow''{{'s}} second season, with the planned backdoor pilot cancelled in favor of a traditional pilot by The CW executives, who had been impressed by early cuts of Barry's first two episodes on ''Arrow''. This allowed the creative team to flesh out Barry's story and his world on a bigger budget, as opposed to a backdoor pilot's constraint of incorporating characters from the parent show. The pilot was officially ordered on January 29, 2014, and was written by Berlanti, Kreisberg, and Johns, and directed by Nutter.<ref name="DeadlinePilot" /><ref name="PilotOrdered"/> On May 8, 2014, ''The Flash'' was officially picked up as a series, with an initial order of 13 episodes.<ref name="PickUp" /> Three more scripts were ordered in September 2014 following a positive response to newly completed episodes by executives,<ref name="Deadline3">{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/09/the-flash-jane-the-virgin-additional-scripts-cw-838768/ |title=CW's 'The Flash' & 'Jane The Virgin' Get Backup Script Orders Ahead Of Premieres |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=September 23, 2014 |accessdate=September 24, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140925082725/http://deadline.com/2014/09/the-flash-jane-the-virgin-additional-scripts-cw-838768/ |archivedate=September 25, 2014}}</ref> while a back ten was ordered the next month for a full 23-episode season.<ref name="S1SeasonOrder" />
With the commencement of production on the series' second season, former ''Arrow'' and ''[[Ugly Betty]]'' writer [[Gabrielle Stanton]] was promoted to executive producer and showrunner; after having served as consulting producer and writer on the first season's finale "Fast Enough".<ref name="Stanton1">{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2015/08/17/once-upon-a-time-season-5-belle-merida-spoilers/ |title=Matt's Inside Line: Scoop on Once, Arrow, Castle, The Flash, Scandal, Gotham, Reign, Haven and More |last=Webb Mitovich |first=Matt |work=[[TV Line]] |date=August 17, 2015 |accessdate=August 18, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150818064756/http://tvline.com/2015/08/17/once-upon-a-time-season-5-belle-merida-spoilers/ |archivedate=August 18, 2015}}</ref> However, it was later reported that Kreisberg would be returning to sole showrunner duties at an unspecified time.<ref name="THRdeal">{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/andrew-kreisberg-deal-warner-bros-831387 |title='The Flash' Boss Andrew Kreisberg Inks Overall Deal With Warner Bros. TV (Exclusive) |first=Lesley |last=Goldberg |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=November 3, 2013 |accessdate=November 3, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106004350/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/andrew-kreisberg-deal-warner-bros-831387 |archivedate=November 6, 2015}}</ref> That time was later proved to be at the start of 2016, "Potential Energy", when Stanton was no longer credited as being involved with the show. In May 2017, it was reported that [[Aaron and Todd Helbing|Aaron Helbing]] would be departing the series. Helbing had served as a writer since the first season, and as co-showrunner, along with his brother [[Aaron and Todd Helbing|Todd]] and Kreisberg, since the second.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://comicbook.com/dc/2017/05/22/aaron-helbing-off-the-flash-in-season-4/ |title=Aaron Helbing Off the Flash in Season 4 |last=Burlingame |first=Russ |publisher=Comicbook.com |date=May 22, 2017 |accessdate=July 4, 2017}}</ref>
===Design=== The costume was designed by [[Colleen Atwood]], who also designed the costumes for ''Arrow''.<ref name="Costume" /> It features a burgundy color scheme, a masked helmet, and gold accents throughout,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2578617/First-photo-Grant-Gustin-costume-The-Flash-new-TV-series-revealed.html |title=Ride the lightning! First photo of Grant Gustin in costume as The Flash for new TV series revealed |publisher=DailyMail |accessdate=December 23, 2014 |date=March 11, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141223170659/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2578617/First-photo-Grant-Gustin-costume-The-Flash-new-TV-series-revealed.html |archivedate=December 23, 2014}}</ref> and went through multiple adjustments from the moment it was placed in computer renderings to the day of filming the pilot.<ref name="AccessHoll"/> Primarily made of leather, the suit contains areas with a stretchable material to allow Gustin room to bend. According to Atwood "It was all about a costume that could sell speed, Grant [Gustin] was continually moving in the suit, so it had to be designed to make that all happen visually and functionally."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://fashionista.com/2015/03/superhero-costume-design |title=How Superhero Costumes are Made |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2015 |website= |publisher= |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Yag1w5Nr?url=http://fashionista.com/2015/03/superhero-costume-design |archivedate=May 17, 2015}}</ref> It initially took Gustin approximately 40 minutes to get into his costume, as the first cowl was prosthetic and had to be zipped and glued to his face. This was cut down to approximately 15 minutes by episode eight, when designers were able to develop a new cowl that easily slid over Gustin's face and locked into place.<ref name="AccessHoll"/> Maya Mani replaced Atwood as the costume designer for the second season and made slight changes to the Flash costume, such as changing the color of his crest from yellow to white, being faithful to the Flash costume from the comics.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://fashionista.com/2015/09/fall-tv-costume-design-october |title=Costume secrets from the upcoming seasons of 'Reign,' 'The Good Wife' and more |date=September 28, 2015 |website=Fashionista |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929040254/http://fashionista.com/2015/09/fall-tv-costume-design-october |archive-date=September 29, 2015 |dead-url=no |access-date=September 29, 2015}}</ref>
===Filming=== Production on the pilot began in March 2014, with filming taking place in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vancitybuzz.com/2014/03/flash-runs-past-vancouver-art-gallery/ |title=Flash Running After Villains in Vancouver (Photos & Videos) |publisher=Vancity Buzz |date=March 2014 |accessdate=June 25, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140621050930/http://www.vancitybuzz.com/2014/03/flash-runs-past-vancouver-art-gallery/ |archivedate=June 21, 2014}}</ref> additional filming for the series takes place in [[Portland, Oregon]].<ref name="PortlandFilming" /> On how action sequences are shot for the series, compared to ''Arrow'', Gustin said, "When [''Arrow''] shoot[s] action sequences, pretty much what you see is what you get and they're really doing everything. We do a lot of plate shots that are empty shots of the area we're going to be in and then they're putting us in later in [[Post-production|post]]. I do a lot of the fighting. I don't have to do it full speed and then they ramp it up and a lot of people have to freeze and I keep moving. Then I have to clear frame and step back into frame. It's really tedious stuff that we have to do. On theirs, they learn fight choreography and they shoot it from the perfect angles and what you see is what you get."<ref name="FightShooting" /> Production on the third season began in early July 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cosmicbooknews.com/content/flash-season-3-started-filming |title=The Flash Season 3 Started Filming |publisher=Cosmic Book News |accessdate=July 9, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160710052206/http://www.cosmicbooknews.com/content/flash-season-3-started-filming |archivedate=July 10, 2016}}</ref>
===Music=== ''Arrow'' composer [[Blake Neely]] is the primary composer of the series, and was first hired in April 2014 to score the pilot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/04/10/blake-neely-to-score-the-cws-the-flash/ |title=Blake Neely to Score The CW's 'The Flash' |publisher=''Film Music Reporter'' |date=April 10, 2014 |accessdate=August 5, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925110912/http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/04/10/blake-neely-to-score-the-cws-the-flash/ |archivedate=September 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Neely" /> He had previously composed a theme for Barry Allen which was featured in ''Arrow''{{'}}s [[List of Arrow episodes#Season 2 (2013–14)|season two]] episodes "The Scientist" and "Three Ghosts". The theme was titled "The Scientist" when it was released on the [[Arrow (TV series)#Music|''Arrow: Season 2'' soundtrack]]. According to Neely, "It had to be different [from ''Arrow''] ... but it also couldn't be so different that it couldn't fit in the ''Arrow'' universe, ... it had to be in a style that could hold hands with ''Arrow''."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Neely |first1=Blake |title=CBR TV: Super Composer Finds "Flash" & "Arrow" Inspiration for "Legends," Makes "Supergirl" Fun |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/cbr-tv-super-composer-finds-flash-arrow-inspiration-for-legends-makes-supergirl-fun |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=September 14, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920100039/http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/cbr-tv-super-composer-finds-flash-arrow-inspiration-for-legends-makes-supergirl-fun |archivedate=September 20, 2015}}</ref> On December 18, 2014, WaterTower Music released a selection of music from ''The Flash''/''Arrow'' crossover episodes, as well as two bonus tracks from their respective 2014 midseason finales.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.watertower-music.com/releases_spotlight.php?search=WTM39625 |title=The Flash vs. Arrow: Music Selections from the Epic 2-Night Event |work=WaterTower Music |accessdate=December 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220000519/http://www.watertower-music.com/releases_spotlight.php?search=WTM39625 |archivedate=December 20, 2014}}</ref> The first season, two-disc soundtrack was released on October 16, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2015/08/12/la-la-land-records-to-release-soundtrack-album-for-the-cws-the-flash/ |title=La-La Land Records to Release Soundtrack Album for The CW's 'The Flash' |publisher=Film Music Reporter |date=August 12, 2015 |accessdate=September 14, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925104507/http://filmmusicreporter.com/2015/08/12/la-la-land-records-to-release-soundtrack-album-for-the-cws-the-flash/ |archivedate=September 25, 2015}}</ref> The second season's soundtrack was released digitally on July 22, 2016,<ref>{{cite web |title=The Flash: Original Television Soundtrack – Season 2 |url=http://www.watertower-music.com/releases/release.php?title=flash2 |website=WaterTower Music |publisher=WaterTower Music |accessdate=August 3, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819002607/http://www.watertower-music.com/releases/release.php?title=flash2 |archivedate=August 19, 2016}}</ref> and in CD format on July 26, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=THE FLASH – SEASON 2 |website=La-La Land Records |publisher=La-La Land Records |accessdate=August 3, 2016}}</ref>
===Sound design=== The sound design for the show is handled by Mark Camperell. The sound effect for Barry is made up of elements of thunder, electricity, jets, fireballs, and various custom whooshes and impacts. Speaking about designing the sound for The Flash's ability, Mark says: "My approach for the sounds of The Flash's ability was to editorially treat him like a really aggressively driven hot rod. This doesn't mean that I used car sounds for him, though. What I mean is that when thinking about how to edit his sounds, I thought about it like cutting a car chase."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asoundeffect.com/the-flash-sound-design/ |title=Sounds for Superheroes: Behind the Supersonic Sound Design for The Flash |publisher=Asoundeffect.com |date=October 5, 2015 |accessdate=October 6, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006181824/http://www.asoundeffect.com/the-flash-sound-design/ |archivedate=October 6, 2015}}</ref>
==Broadcast== <!--Do not add channels to this list. We are not a TV guide. If you do so, it will be reverted.--> ''The Flash'' was screened at the Warner Bros. Television and DC Entertainment panel at [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] in July 2014.<ref name="PilotComicCon" /> The series officially premiered on [[The CW]] on October 7, 2014, during the [[2014–15 United States network television schedule|2014–15 television season]]<ref name="premiere">{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/06/25/the-cw-announces-fall-premiere-dates/ |title=The CW Announces Fall Premiere Dates |last=Bibel |first=Sara |website=TV by the Numbers |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=June 25, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714161634/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/06/25/the-cw-announces-fall-premiere-dates/ |archivedate=July 14, 2014}}</ref> and also premiered in [[Canada]] on the same night.<ref name="cashowstart">{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/thectvinsider/articles/news/ctv_premieres.aspx/ |title=CTV Fall 2014 lineup premiere dates announced |publisher=CTV |date=July 29, 2014 |accessdate=September 30, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006073414/http://www.ctv.ca/thectvinsider/articles/news/ctv_premieres.aspx/ |archivedate=October 6, 2014}}</ref> The second episode was screened at [[New York Comic Con]] on October 9, 2014, as a way to repay the viewers that watched the series' premiere episode.<ref name="Ep2ComicConScreen" /> The series premiered in the United Kingdom and Ireland on October 28, 2014,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Flash-UK-premiere/story-23060198-detail/story.html |title=When is The Flash UK premiere? |last=Tidesw |first=Martin |work=The Sentinel (Staffordshire) |date=October 8, 2014 |accessdate=November 3, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220084804/http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/Flash-UK-premiere/story-23060198-detail/story.html |archivedate=December 20, 2014}}</ref> and in Australia on December 3, 2014.<ref name="aushowstart">{{cite web |url=http://www.foxtel.com.au/whats-on/foxtel-insider/jane-the-virgin-and-the-flash-premiere-on-fox8-239971.htm |title=Jane the Virgin and The Flash: Premiere on Fox8 |publisher=[[Foxtel]] |date=November 10, 2014 |accessdate=January 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141224194710/http://www.foxtel.com.au/whats-on/foxtel-insider/jane-the-virgin-and-the-flash-premiere-on-fox8-239971.htm |archivedate=December 24, 2014}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical response===

style="padding:0 8px;" | [[Rotten Tomatoes]] ! style="padding:0 8px;" | [[Metacritic]] |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#97B5CC;"| | 1 | 97% (65 reviews)<ref name="S1RT">{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/flash/s01 |title=The Flash: Season 1 (2014–2015) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=June 26, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012003025/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/flash/s01 |archivedate=October 12, 2017}}</ref> | 73 (27 reviews)<ref name="S1MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-flash-2014 |title=The Flash: Season 1 (2014–2015) Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=October 12, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171012010124/http://www.metacritic.com/tv/the-flash-2014 |archivedate=October 12, 2017}}</ref> |- ! scope="row" style="width:12px; background:#712422;"| | 5 | 95% (41 reviews)<ref name="S5RT">{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/flash/s05 |title=The Flash: Season 5 (2018) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=October 28, 2018}}</ref> | {{N/a}} |- |}
Regarding Gustin's debut as Barry Allen in ''Arrow'' and the potential for a series, [[IGN]]'s Jesse Schedeen stated his concern: "Gustin doesn't come across as leading man material. His awkward bumbling intertwining with Felicity's was cute, but rarely did I get the impression that this character could or should be given his own spinoff series."<ref name="IGNScientistReview" /> Schedeen eventually warmed up to the character, however, once the "dorkiness and social awkwardness" were downplayed a bit and the emphasis was placed on "his keen scientific mind".<ref name="IGNBlastRadiusReview" />
The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported a 97% approval rating with an average rating of 7.5/10 based on 58 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "''The Flash'' benefits from its purposefully light atmosphere, making it a superhero show uniquely geared toward genre fans as well as novices."<ref name="S1RT" /> [[Metacritic]], which uses a weighted average, assigned a score of 73 out of 100, based on 27 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref name="S1MC" /> IGN's Eric Goldman and Joshua Yehl praised the show's premise and cast after viewing a press screening copy of the pilot. Goldman and Yehl favorably compared it to ''Arrow'', stating that ''The Flash'' progresses with a confidence that ''Arrow'' did not get until later in the series.<ref name="IGNPilotThoughts" /> Reviews for the series became increasingly positive as the season progressed, with the finale receiving critical acclaim. Noel Murray of [[The A.V. Club]] gave the season a B+ overall, giving praise to the pacing of the plot, the performances of the cast and the special effects, and also pointing out the series' boldness to embrace its comic book influences, something that conventional superhero shows tend not to do.<ref name="AVClubS1">{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/review/flashs-first-season-brought-fun-back-live-action-s-219446 |last=Murray |first=Noel |title=The Flash's first season brought the fun back to live-action superheroes |publisher=The Onion A.V. Club |date=May 19, 2015 |accessdate=June 12, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612101405/http://www.avclub.com/review/flashs-first-season-brought-fun-back-live-action-s-219446 |archivedate=June 12, 2015}}</ref> Weekly episode reviewer Scott Von Doviak gave consistently high ratings to the season and awarded the season finale a perfect A grade, calling the episode "richly satisfying" and also commending the show for "[capturing] the essence of its source material in a fun, light-on-its-feet way that few other comic book adaptations have managed." He also gave high praise to the emotional value and performances of the cast, as well as the cliffhanger and multiple easter eggs found in the episode.<ref name="S1FinaleAVClub">{{cite web |url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/flash-fast-enough-219671 |title=The Flash: "Fast Enough" |last=Von Doviak |first=Scott |publisher=The Onion A.V. Club |date=May 19, 2015 |accessdate=June 12, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150614214116/http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/flash-fast-enough-219671 |archivedate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> The second season of ''The Flash'' scored a [[Metacritic]] rating of 81 out of 100 indicating "universal acclaim".<ref name="S2MC" />
In 2016, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked the show #23 on its list of the "40 Best Science Fiction TV Shows of All Time".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/lists/40-best-science-fiction-tv-shows-20160526 |title=40 Best Science Fiction TV Shows of All Time |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |last=Adams |first=Sam |date=May 26, 2016 |accessdate=June 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527141422/http://www.rollingstone.com/tv/lists/40-best-science-fiction-tv-shows-20160526 |archivedate=May 27, 2016}}</ref>

===Ratings=== The first episode of ''The Flash'' was watched by 4.8 million viewers and had a 1.9 18–49 demographic rating, making it The CW's most watched and highest rated series premiere since ''[[The Vampire Diaries]]'' in 2009. It also became The CW's second-most watched series premiere ever, behind ''[[90210 (TV series)|90210]]'', and the third-highest rated in the 18–49 demographic.<ref name="S1PremiereRatings" /> Factoring Live + 7 day ratings, the pilot was watched by a total of 6.8 million viewers, becoming The CW's most-watched telecast and the highest-rated premiere among men 18–34 (2.5 rating). It broke the previous record for the most-watched telecast held by the [[America's Next Top Model (cycle 8)|cycle 8 finale of ''America's Next Top Model'']] in 2007 (6.69 million). Additionally, across all platforms, including initiated streams on digital platforms and total unduplicated viewers on-air over two airings the week of October 7, 2014, the premiere was seen more than 13 million times.<ref name="S1PremiereLive7" />
<!--Do not add international ratings for every episode or ratings tables for every country. It clutters the article and we aren't an indiscriminate collection of information. Once episode articles are created, they can be added to the respective episode.--> The Canadian premiere was watched by 3.11 million viewers, making it the most-watched broadcast that night and the second for that week.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://assets.numeris.ca/Downloads/October%206-October%2012,%202014%20(National).pdf |title=Top 30 Programs (October 6–12, 2014) |work=Numeris |date=October 21, 2014 |accessdate=February 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022153930/http://assets.numeris.ca/Downloads/October%206-October%2012%2C%202014%20%28National%29.pdf |archivedate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> In the United Kingdom, the premiere was the fourth highest-rated broadcast of the week and the eleventh of that month, with 1.53 million viewers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-30? |title=Weekly Top 30 |publisher=Broadcasters' Audience Research Board |accessdate=February 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wSLX6Azh?url=http://www.barb.co.uk/report/weeklyTopProgrammesOverview |archivedate=February 13, 2011}} Note: The ratings must be searched for.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/monthly-top-30? |title=Monthly Top 30 |publisher=Broadcasters' Audience Research Board |accessdate=February 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220204506/http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/monthly-top-30 |archivedate=February 20, 2015}} Note: The ratings must be searched for.</ref> The timeshifted version got 82,000 viewers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-10? |title=Weekly Top 10 |publisher=Broadcasters' Audience Research Board |accessdate=February 20, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718204656/http://www.barb.co.uk/whats-new/weekly-top-10 |archivedate=July 18, 2014}} Note: The ratings must be searched for.</ref> The premiere in Australia was the most-watched broadcast on pay television, with 129,000 viewers tuning in.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2014/12/wednesday-3-december-2014.html |title=Wednesday 3 December 2014 |date=December 4, 2014 |last=Knox |first=David |publisher=TV Tonight |accessdate=February 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220204907/http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2014/12/wednesday-3-december-2014.html |archivedate=February 20, 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, according to an analysis from Parrot Analytics, which used ratings data (where available), peer-to-peer sharing, social media chatter, and other factors to estimate viewer demand for various shows, ''The Flash'' was the 5th most popular show in the world with 3.1 million demand expressions per day, behind ''[[Game of Thrones]]'', ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]'', ''[[Pretty Little Liars]]'', and ''[[Westworld (TV series)|Westworld]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/most-popular-tv-shows-2016-12/#1-hbos-game-of-thrones-with-72-million-demand-expressions-per-day-people-around-the-world-were-desperate-to-learn-the-fate-of-jon-snow-and-watch-the-rise-of-daenerys-targaryen-as-the-epic-adaptation-moved-past-the-novels-into-uncharted-territory-1 |title=The 20 most popular TV shows of 2016 |work=[[Business Insider]] |last=Lubin |first=Gus |date=December 30, 2016 |accessdate=January 1, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170101002433/http://www.businessinsider.com/most-popular-tv-shows-2016-12/ |archivedate=January 1, 2017}}</ref> [[TorrentFreak]] also gauged ''The Flash'' as the fourth most-[[Torrent file|torrented]] television show of 2016.<ref name="thirdfreak">{{cite web |url=https://torrentfreak.com/game-of-thrones-most-torrented-tv-show-of-2016-161226/ |title='Game of Thrones' Most Torrented TV-Show of 2016 |first=Ernesto |last=Van der Sar |date=December 26, 2016 |website=[[TorrentFreak]] |publisher=[[TorrentFreak|TF Publishing]] |accessdate=December 30, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161226175113/https://torrentfreak.com/game-of-thrones-most-torrented-tv-show-of-2016-161226/ |archivedate=December 26, 2016}}</ref>

==Other media==
===Digital comic=== ''The Flash: Season Zero'', written by Kreisberg, [[Brooke Eikmeier]] and Katherine Walczak, with art by [[Phil Hester (comics)|Phil Hester]] and Eric Gapstur, is intended to take place between the pilot episode and episode 2. Kreisberg stated, "Barry will [already] be the Flash, he will have his team, everyone will be in that world, and we'll{{sic}} introducing a new set of villains that we won't be seeing on the TV show. It'll feel like the same heart, humor and spectacle that you get watching ''Flash''." The comic will showcase the entire TV cast, plus new rogues, a group of circus performers who gained super powers as a result of the S.T.A.R. Labs particle accelerator explosion. The group is led by [[Bliss (Starman)|Mr. Bliss]], a character who first appeared in ''[[Starman (comics)#Titles|Starman]]''. The comic launched digitally biweekly on September 8, 2014, with its first physical release featuring a collection of the digital releases, releasing on October 1.<ref name="Comic" />
===''The Chronicles of Cisco''=== On February 24, 2015, The CW launched a [[Tumblr]] account known as ''The Chronicles of Cisco''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Get to know the man, AND the metahumans he takes care of in...The Chronicles of Cisco! |url=https://twitter.com/CW_TheFlash/status/570388554607505408 |website=Twitter |publisher=The Flash}}</ref> The blog features posts written by the fictional character of [[Vibe (comics)|Cisco Ramon]], at first serving as write-ups of the metahuman villains on the show. Starting with the second season of the show, the posts evolved into the general musings of Ramon and his commentary on the events during and outside of ''The Flash'''s episodes.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Chronicles of Cisco |url=http://chroniclesofcisco.tumblr.com/ |website=Tumblr |accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref>
===Promotional shorts===
====''Chronicles of Cisco: Entry 0419''==== On April 19, 2016, a four-episode series of shorts, titled ''Chronicles of Cisco: Entry 0419'', premiered. The series, which was presented by [[AT&T]], features Valdes and [[Britne Oldford]] reprise their role as Cisco Ramon and [[Peek-a-Boo (comics)|Shawna Baez / Peek-a-Boo]], respectively. Set in the second season of the television series, the series sees Cisco attempting to make the Flash suit bulletproof and body-odor proof. While working on these, he receives a late-night Meta-Human Alert within S.T.A.R. Labs,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://comicbook.com/dc/2016/04/19/the-flash-chronicles-of-cisco-part-1-released/ |title=The Flash: Chronicles Of Cisco Part 1 Released |last=Siegel |first=Lucas |publisher=Comicbook.com |date=April 19, 2016 |accessdate=April 19, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420122510/http://comicbook.com/dc/2016/04/19/the-flash-chronicles-of-cisco-part-1-released/ |archivedate=April 20, 2016}}</ref> and learns that Peek-a-Boo triggered the alert.<ref>{{cite av media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wgC0KrU0Oac |title=The Flash Chronicles of Cisco: Entry 0419 – Part 2 The CW |author=The CW Television Network |publisher=YouTube |date=April 26, 2016 |accessdate=April 27, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505100236/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wgC0KrU0Oac |archivedate=May 5, 2016}}</ref> She has come to S.T.A.R. Labs to make Cisco create a weapon for her, as he did for Golden Glider, Captain Cold, and Heatwave. When he does not cooperate, she shoots him.<ref>{{cite av media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qLsLzvp-dSs |title=The Flash <nowiki>|</nowiki> Chronicles of Cisco: Entry 0419 – Part 3 <nowiki>|</nowiki> The CW |author=The CW Television Network |publisher=YouTube |date=May 3, 2016 |accessdate=May 4, 2016}}</ref> Cisco survives being shot, realizing that the orange soda he spilt on his shirt was the missing catalyst to his bulletproof formula. Cisco tries to bring Peek-a-Boo back to the pipeline, but she locks him in the cell instead. Cisco is then seen being woken up due to a call from Barry. He believes he dreamt the whole experience, until he finds the bullet that shot him on the ground.<ref>{{cite av media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JkrW71ysm_w |title=The Flash Chronicles of Cisco: Entry 0419 – Part 4 The CW |author=The CW Television Network |publisher=YouTube |date=May 10, 2016 |accessdate=May 11, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160716055039/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JkrW71ysm_w |archivedate=July 16, 2016}}</ref>
====''Stretched Scenes''==== On November 14, 2017, a three-episode series of shorts, known as "Stretched Scenes", premiered. The series, presented by [[Microsoft Surface]], features [[Hartley Sawyer]], [[Danielle Panabaker]], and [[Candice Patton]] as [[Elongated Man|Ralph Dibny]], [[Caitlin Snow (Arrowverse)|Cailtin Snow]], and [[Iris West]] respectively. Set during the [[The Flash (season 4)|show's fourth season]], it shows Dibny as he continually bothers Cailtin and Iris for their help, or for attention. The shorts premiered online as well as during the commercial breaks of the episodes [[The Flash (season 4)#ep75|"When Harry Met Harry..."]], [[The Flash (season 4)#ep76|"Therefore I Am"]], and [[The Flash (season 4)#ep78|"Don't Run"]].<ref>{{cite web |title=The Flash 4x06 Sneak Peek "When Harry Met Harry…" (HD) Season 4 Episode 6 Sneak Peek |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5sQ0WaTrvSY |website=YouTube |publisher=TV Promos |accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Flash 4x07 Sneak Peek #2 "Therefore I Am" (HD) Season 4 Episode 7 Sneak Peek #2 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y1WNHYWIxA8 |website=YouTube |publisher=TV Promos |accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Flash 4x09 Sneak Peek "Don't Run" (HD) Season 4 Episode 9 Sneak Peek Mid-Season Finale |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q-EwHPqwcqQ |website=YouTube |publisher=TV Promos |accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
===Video games=== The series has also been featured in other video games based off DC Comics property. In the mobile version of ''[[Injustice: Gods Among Us]]'', the show's versions of the Flash and Reverse-Flash appear as alternate costumes for the Flash.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Parungo |first1=Nicolo |title='Injustice' mobile game update adds Reverse Flash, Arkham Knight, Survival Mode and more |url=http://www.ibtimes.com.au/injustice-mobile-game-update-adds-reverse-flash-arkham-knight-survival-mode-more-1477516 |website=International Business Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025131328/http://www.ibtimes.com.au/injustice-mobile-game-update-adds-reverse-flash-arkham-knight-survival-mode-more-1477516 |archivedate=October 25, 2015}}</ref> The show's version of S.T.A.R. Labs also appears as a hidden area in ''[[Lego Dimensions]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=LEGO Dimensions CW's The Flash Easter Egg Mini Level (Chapter 5 of Fantastic Beasts) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W1UJ6KX94bM |website=Youtube.com |accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref> In September 2018, Warner Bros. announced that the season pass for the game ''[[Lego DC Super-Villains]]'' would included content inspired by ''The Flash''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nunneley |first1=Stephany |title=LEGO DC Super-Villains Season Pass contains six Level Packs and four Character Packs |url=https://www.vg247.com/2018/09/01/lego-dc-super-villains-season-pass-contents/ |website=VG 24/7 |accessdate=2 September 2018}}</ref>
===Books=== ====Novels==== On November 29, 2016, [[Titan Books]] released ''Flash: The Haunting of Barry Allen'', a tie-in novelization written by Susan and Clay Griffith, set during the course of the second season, after Barry has closed the temporal anomaly that nearly destroyed Central City. Barry must seek help from Oliver Queen, due to his own abilities beginning to break down, in order to deal with five members of his Rogues Gallery—including Pied Piper, Weather Wizard, and Peekaboo.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Griffith |first1=Clay |last2=Griffith |first2=Susan |title=Flash: The Haunting of Barry Allen |date=November 29, 2016 |publisher=[[Titan Books]] |isbn=9781785651410 |pages=1–416}}</ref> The story continued in ''Arrow — A Generation of Vipers'', released on March 28, 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Arrow-Generation-Vipers-Susan-Griffith/dp/178329485X/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1480973429&sr=1-2 |title=Arrow - A Generation of Vipers |work=Amazon |accessdate=January 3, 2017}}</ref> A subsequent novel, following the villain [[Weather Wizard]] in his attempts at revenge, was released in May 2018. Written by [[Richard A. Knaak]], it is titled ''The Flash: Climate Changeling''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://titanbooks.com/the-flash-climate-changeling-8733/ |title=The Flash: Climate Changeling |publisher="Titan Books" |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref>
In October, 2017, [[Abrams Books]] started a new trilogy of ''The Flash'' novels, written by [[Barry Lyga]], aimed at middle-grade readers in tandem with a similar trilogy of ''Supergirl'' novels.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Serrao |first1=Nivea |title=''The Flash'' and ''Supergirl'' to get middle-grade novels |url=https://ew.com/books/2017/05/30/flash-supergirl-middle-grade-novels/ |website=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref> The first, ''The Flash: Hocus Pocus'', was released on October 3, 2017. The novel takes place in an alternate timeline where the show's [[List of The Flash episodes#ep47|"Flashpoint" event]] never occurred, and The Flash must fight a villain known as Hocus Pocus who can control the minds and actions of people.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Flash-Hocus-Pocus-Book/dp/1419728156 |title=The Flash: Hocus Pocus |work=Amazon |accessdate=August 24, 2018}}</ref> A sequel, ''The Flash: Johnny Quick'' was released on April 3, 2018,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Flash-Johnny-Quick-Barry-Lyga/dp/1419728652/ |title=The Flash: Johnny Quick |work=Amazon |accessdate=August 24, 2018}}</ref> as well as a third novel, titled ''The Flash: The Tornado Twins'', on October 2, 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Flash-Tornado-Twins-Book/dp/1419731246/ |title=The Flash: Tornado Twins |work=Amazon |accessdate=August 24, 2018}}</ref>
====Behind-the-scenes==== On October 21, 2016, "The Art and Making of The Flash" by Abbie Bernstein was released. This is a 160-page behind-the-scenes book with production art and behind-the-scenes photography. The book also includes interviews with the cast and crew from the show.<ref>[http://birthmoviesdeath.com/2016/10/24/the-art-and-making-of-the-flash-review BirthMoviesDeath: THE ART AND MAKING OF THE FLASH Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523122658/http://birthmoviesdeath.com/2016/10/24/the-art-and-making-of-the-flash-review |date=May 23, 2017 }}</ref>

==Arrowverse and the DC multiverse== {{main|Arrowverse}} In January 2015, The CW president Mark Pedowitz announced the intention to do a ''Flash''/''Arrow'' crossover every season,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/CW-Renewals-Beauty-Beast-1091649.aspx |title=The CW Renews Supernatural and 7 More — But Where's Beauty and the Beast? |last=Nguyen |first=Hanh |work=[[TV Guide]] |date=January 11, 2015 |accessdate=January 11, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6q7XKQlWt?url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/cw-renewals-beauty-beast-1091649/ |archivedate=April 30, 2017}}</ref> and The CW announced that an animated web-series, ''[[Vixen (web series)|Vixen]]'', featuring the DC heroine [[Vixen (comics)|of the same name]] and set in the universe of ''Arrow'' and ''The Flash'', would be debuting on [[CW Seed]] in late 2015.<ref name="Vixen1">{{cite news |url=http://www.ksitetv.com/vixen/dc-comics-vixen-coming-to-cw-seed/52484 |title=DC Comics' Vixen Coming To CW Seed |work=KSiteTV |date=January 11, 2015 |accessdate=January 11, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150112060742/http://www.ksitetv.com/vixen/dc-comics-vixen-coming-to-cw-seed/52484 |archivedate=January 12, 2015}}</ref> The character is expected to make a live-action appearance on ''Arrow'' and/or ''The Flash'' as well.<ref name="Vixen2">{{cite news |url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/flash-arrow-universe-expansion-supernatural-spinoff-hart-dixie-mark-pedowitz-cw-1201347209/ |title=The CW's Mark Pedowitz On Expanding Flash-Arrow Universe, 'Dixie's Future, Another 'Supernatural' Spinoff & More |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=January 11, 2015 |accessdate=January 11, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114062718/http://deadline.com/2015/01/flash-arrow-universe-expansion-supernatural-spinoff-hart-dixie-mark-pedowitz-cw-1201347209/ |archivedate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> The next month, it was reported that a spin-off series, which is described as a superhero team-up show, was in discussion by The CW for a possible [[2015–16 United States network television schedule|2015–16]] midseason release. Berlanti and Kreisberg would executive produce alongside Guggenheim and Sarah Schechter. The potential series would be headlined by several recurring characters from both ''Arrow'' and ''The Flash'', with the potential for other ''Arrow''/''Flash'' characters to cross over to the new series as well.<ref name="All1">{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2015/02/arrow-flash-spin-off-cw-new-superhero-series-1201382466/ |title=Arrow/Flash Superhero Team-Up Spinoff In Works At CW; Brandon Routh, Victor Garber, Wentworth Miller, Caity Lotz Star |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=February 26, 2015 |accessdate=February 27, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227033833/http://deadline.com/2015/02/arrow-flash-spin-off-cw-new-superhero-series-1201382466/ |archivedate=February 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/dominic-purcell-cast-arrow-flash-spinoff-heat-wave-cw-1201393858/ |title=Dominic Purcell Joins Arrow/Flash Spinoff |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=March 16, 2015 |accessdate=March 16, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318041408/http://deadline.com/2015/03/dominic-purcell-cast-arrow-flash-spinoff-heat-wave-cw-1201393858/ |archivedate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> In May 2015, The CW officially picked up the series, titled ''[[Legends of Tomorrow|DC's Legends of Tomorrow]]''.<ref name="LegendsOfTomorrow">{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/05/07/dcs-legends-of-tomorrow-crazy-ex-girlfriend-cordon-ordered-to-series-by-the-cw/ |title='DC's Legends of Tomorrow', 'Crazy Ex-Girlfriend' & 'Cordon' Ordered to Series by The CW |last=Kondolojy |first=Amanda |work=[[TV by the Numbers]] |date=May 7, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518082354/http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/05/07/dcs-legends-of-tomorrow-crazy-ex-girlfriend-cordon-ordered-to-series-by-the-cw/ |archivedate=May 18, 2015}}</ref>
The second season begins to explore the concept of the multiverse, by introducing Earth-2, which features doppelgängers of the inhabitants in the Arrowverse (or Earth-1), along with [[Flash (Jay Garrick)|Jay Garrick]], the Flash of Earth-2, and [[Zoom (comics)|Zoom]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/Flash-Feature-Earth-2-Earlier-Than-Expected-77097.html |title=The Flash Will Feature Earth 2 Earlier Than Expected |last=Holmes |first=Adam |publisher=Cinema Blend |date=August 2015 |accessdate=February 10, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216060518/http://www.cinemablend.com/television/Flash-Feature-Earth-2-Earlier-Than-Expected-77097.html |archivedate=February 16, 2016}}</ref> In the episode "[[List of The Flash (2014 TV series) episodes#ep36|Welcome to Earth-2]]", as Barry, Cisco and Harrison Wells of Earth-2 travel to Earth-2, glimpses of the multiverse are seen, including an image of ''[[Supergirl (TV series)|Supergirl]]'' star [[Melissa Benoist]] as [[Supergirl (Kara Zor-El)|Supergirl]] and an image of [[John Wesley Shipp]] as the Flash from the [[The Flash (1990 TV series)|1990 television series]], implying the two characters and their respective television series exist on alternate Earths to the Arrowverse;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/surprising-dc-superhero-makes-cameo-flash |title=Surprising DC Superhero Makes Cameo On "The Flash" |last=Couto |first=Anthony |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |date=February 9, 2016 |accessdate=February 9, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160212195031/http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/surprising-dc-superhero-makes-cameo-flash |archivedate=February 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/flash-teases-dc-tv-future-retro-continuity-with-multiple-surprise-cameos |title="Flash" Teases DC TV Future, Retro Continuity With Multiple Surprise Cameos |last=Couto |first=Anthony |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |date=February 9, 2016 |accessdate=February 9, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160211090040/http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/flash-teases-dc-tv-future-retro-continuity-with-multiple-surprise-cameos |archivedate=February 11, 2016}}</ref> ''Supergirl''{{'}}s world is later designated Earth-38 in the Arrowverse multiverse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://collider.com/the-flash-recap-invasion/ |title='The Flash' Recap: "Invasion!" – The Gang's All Here |last=Day |first=Carla |publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |date=November 29, 2016 |accessdate=November 30, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130190328/http://collider.com/the-flash-recap-invasion/ |archivedate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> Gustin as Barry appeared on the eighteenth episode of ''Supergirl'', "[[Worlds Finest]]", which aired on CBS on March 28, 2016. Intersecting with the events of the eighteenth episode of ''The Flash'', which aired on April 19, 2016, Barry accidentally arrives on Earth-38 and helps Kara battle two of her enemies, [[Silver Banshee]] ([[Italia Ricci]]) and [[Livewire (comics)|Livewire]] ([[Brit Morgan]]), before returning home.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pedersen |first1=Erik |title=''Supergirl'' & ''The Flash'' Crossover Promo: A Double-DC Tease |url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/supergirl-the-flash-crossover-teaser-melissa-benoist-grant-guston-1201721136/ |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=March 16, 2016 |accessdate=March 17, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319011225/https://deadline.com/2016/03/supergirl-the-flash-crossover-teaser-melissa-benoist-grant-guston-1201721136/ |archivedate=March 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/18/supergirl-flash-crossover-spoilers |title=On the set: Everything you need to know about the Flash-Supergirl crossover |last=Abrams |first=Natalie |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=March 18, 2016 |accessdate=March 20, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160320153150/http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/18/supergirl-flash-crossover-spoilers |archivedate=March 20, 2016}}</ref>
